notes: Government forces deploy to Bordor, kill 19 Somalis and 8 Oromos. The reason for the deployment to the area is believed to be a reaction to ethnic strife in the area.

Reported beating of some students from the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST) by police officers. The officers had been captured on video footage attacking the students after arresting them for rioting and causing damage to vehicles.
A man in Merzek was fatally shot by unknown gunmen.
A person is killed in Sirte by a landmine.

admin1: Tajura wa an Nawahi al Arba
notes: African Airlines (AFIA) employees Saturday entered an open sit-in until the company's director of information technology, Fathi Shadi, was released from custody of a Tripoli militia.

actor1: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
notes: Armed clashes broke out on Saturday between a Libyan 'joint-security force' and gunmen in Khoms, killing five people. The gunmen were accused of being involved in a communal clash over land which killed 7 people the previous week
Several young Moroccans and sub-Saharans clashed with stones near the Boulevard La Croix de Casablanca. Vehicles and property is burnt during the clashes
Military forces clear Abusuriwa, Newchina, Bonzon, Usmanari, Goyayeri, Shitimari, Gashimari and Awaram villages in Bama Local Government Area of Boko Haram elements. Eight dead, 30 rescued.
Military forces clear Abusuriwa, Newchina, Bonzon, Usmanari, Goyayeri, Shitimari, Gashimari and Awaram villages in Bama Local Government Area of Boko Haram elements. Eight dead, 30 rescued.
Military forces engage Boko Haram at Kumshe and Dar el Jamal villages, six Boko Haram dead.
Military forces engage Boko Haram at Kumshe and Dar el Jamal villages, six Boko Haram dead.
A journalist is shot and killed by unknown assailants "at the weekend" while on a hunting expedition in Ekiti East LGA.
An oil mogul escapes an assassination attempt by unruly mob in Abonnema. The rioters attacked his car with stones. No reported injury.

Two groups of youths violently protest for and against the postponement of an upcoming election. The unrest lasted two days. Several buildings destroyed. One death reported on the first day.

Air forces destroy a Boko Haram ammunitions base 23km south of Konduga. The strikes took place over two days, though the specific dates are not revealed by the source. An military announcement of the operation was made on 22/11. No reported causalities.

The members of the ad hoc committee who wanted to hear the mayor of Dakar were met with the determination of his souteneurs. Khalifa Sall's relatives soon blocked all the roads leading to Rebeuss Prison. It took the muscled intervention of the police to disperse them.

Striking taxi drivers blocked the convoy of President Museveni on Wednesday 22nd, at the Clock Tower in Kampala, as they demonstrated against monthly taxes that are levied by Kampala Capital City Authority. After about 10 minutes, President Museveni was forced to stop and address them on the matter.
Students from the Christian College of Southern Africa held a protest in Harare to call for an improvement in conditions and an increase in lecturers' wages.

actor1: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
notes: A man wearing a flag in Mbare was beaten by ZANU-PF supporters in the G40 faction, who accused him of causing trouble in the suburb.
2 men who had visited the house of a churchman associated with the G40 faction were arrested by the military and beaten.
Families evicted for the construction of the Presidential Palace staged a sit-in outside the Ministry of the Environment.

actor1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
assoc_actor_2: FNL-R: National Forces of Liberation (Rwasa Faction)
notes: An FNL Rwasa supporter was beaten by Imbonerakure in Buhiga.
Looting: The base of the MÃ©decins Sans FrontiÃ¨re (MSF) organization in Bangassou, in the east of the country, has been looted by armed men. The NGO decided to withdraw its staff following this act.

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: The police, supported by the military, intervened in a protest in Oicha, on Tuesday 21st, killing 1 rioter and injuring one other. The participants marched down the street, breaking and bruning during their passage, to protest the death of a 25 year old student killed on the night of the 20th presumably by the FARDC. The participants were dispersed with tear gas and real bullets. One woman died and another boy was shot in the abdomen.
The military kill four militants in North Sinai
A federal police commander for the north west region of Ethiopia was killed during the night hours in Bahir Dar. The officer was attacked by unidentified assailants at his home.

assoc_actor_1: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea
notes: Two days of clashes between young protesters and police in Conakry over the state of education, which claimed the lives of two teenagers on Monday and Tuesday. At least 15 people were injured. Young people burned tires, dumped garbage cans and clashed with police with stones and slingshots.
Thousands of people including Guinean civil society actors and deputies of the National Assembly protested Tuesday in Conakry against the inhuman trafficking and slavery of blacks in Libya.
Strikes: Over 100 health workers in Lofa County, northern Liberia have reportedly abandoned work in demand of three months' incentives owed them by the Pentecostal Mission Unlimited or PMU.
A woman was non-fatally shot by a random bullet in the city of Sabha.

A number of citizens, activists and jurists organized a demonstration in front of the House of Representatives in Tobruk to ask the council not to extend the mandate of the head of the Audit Bureau, Omar Abed Rabbo al-Barasi.
4 people were killed by Fokonolona militia in a vigilante attack.

At least three people were killed Tuesday in clashes between farmers and herders in southern Niger. According to a "provisional assessment", these clashes in a hamlet in the region of Maradi (south) caused "three deaths, including a village chief", "twelve people missing" and 24  arrested, said the radio .

At least 50 people were killed when a suicide bomber blew himself up in a mosque in  Adamawa State. The attack was blamed on Boko Haram. The blast happened during early morning prayers at the Madina mosque in the Unguwar Shuwa area of Mubi.

assoc_actor_1: NAAPE: National Association of Aircraft Pilots and Engineers
notes: NAAPE pilots protest, shut down Dana Air operations over casualization. The protesters barricaded the airline's ticket offices in one of the airport's terminals.
Students demonstrate in support of an anti-cultism law.

actor1: Military Forces of Puntland (1998-); Marine Police Forces of Puntland (1998-)
notes: PSF, PMPF and Police conducted a joint security operation against ISIS fighters in various locations in Qandala. Operations were reported to be ongoing. There were no reports of immediate casualties or arrests.

Al Shabaab fighters ambushed an government soldier transporting khat near Gasarta village (c. 12 km South East of Baidoa) on the road between Baidoa and Buurhakaba district. The soldier was riding a motorbike. There was a brief exchange of small arms fire after which al Shabaab killed the soldier and the driver of the  motorbike. Al Shabaab fighters burnt the motorbike and khat at the scene. Casualties from al Shabaab could not be established at the time of reporting.

Unconfirmed reports indicated that the SNA commando unit conducted a special operation against al Shabaab explosives base where they apprehended at least 16 militants, including a senior al Shabaab security officer, at Danwale village (c. 20 km North West of Walaweyne district). SNA senior officials stated that the explosives base was destroyed and the name of senior AS official would be declared.
21st November, PM, Qoryoley, Lower Shabelle: Al Shabaab attack a Somali National Army (SNA) position. Security forces repealed the attack, 7 al Shabaab dead.

Al Shabaab fighters conducted an attack against Jajeele clan militias at Maroodile (c. 22 km West of Beletweyne town). There was a brief exchange of small arms fire which lasted for about 20 minutes. Al Shabab fighters took control of the village. Three civilian villagers were abducted by al Shabaab fighters after the attack. The motive behind the abduction was not clear. There were no reports of casualties. Al Shabaab fighters withdrew from the locations of the incident. A second source claims government forces were involved.

SNA forces vacated Qalimow village (c. 24 km North East of Balcad district) for Gololey village (c. 9  km South West of Balcad district. Shortly after SNA vacated the village, armed al Shabaab militants with a battlewagon took control of the village without resistance from government soldiers. Al Shabaab later  vacated from the village early in the morning. There were no reports of casualties.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States
notes: Buur Ellaadhe, Buur Hakaba, Bay: Reports form U.S. Africa Command have stated that a U.S. air strike has been launched against al Shabaab at ivo Buur Ellaadhe. 100 al Shabaab believed dead. A second source states the attack occurred at nearby Doodaale. Al Shabaab later denied the air strike took place. However, locals account witnessing several loud sounds in the area.

actor1: AMISOM: African Union Mission in Somalia (2007-)
notes: A roadside IED targeting an AMISOM convoy exploded near Gumarta village (c. 20 km North East of Barawe district). The explosion slightly damaged an AMISOM truck. There were no reports of human casualties. The perpetrators managed to escape. Al Shabaab claimed responsibility of the attack.

A violent demonstration erupted in Cerigabo after the announcement of the preliminary results of the Somaliland presidential election by NEC. The main opposition party, Wadani, accused the ruling party of rigging their votes. Two people were injured in Cerigabo town. There were no reports of arrests.

A violent demonstration erupted in New Hargeisa and Burao after the announcement of the preliminary results of the Somaliland presidential election by National Electoral Commission (NEC). The main opposition party, Wadani, accused the ruling party of rigging their votes. One person was reportedly injured in Burao. There were no reports of arrests.

A violent demonstration erupted in New Hargeisa and Burao after the announcement of the preliminary results of the Somaliland presidential election by National Electoral Commission (NEC). The main opposition party, Wadani, accused the ruling party of rigging their votes. One person was reportedly injured in Burao. There were no reports of arrests.

Property destruction: Al Shabaab fighters burnt commercial commodities, killed donkeys and destroyed donkey carts transporting goods near Garsaley village (c. 40 km South of Rabdhure). The commercial goods came from Burdhuxunle headed to Wajid district. The owners of the donkey carts managed to escape from the al Shabaab fighters. Some of those who escaped burnt two houses of the two main perpetrators in Wajid district in retaliation to the loss of their property.

The commercial goods came from Burdhuxunle headed to Wajid district. The owners of the donkey carts managed to escape from the al Shabaab fighters. Some of those who escaped burnt two houses of the two main perpetrators in Wajid district in retaliation to the loss of their property.

Al Shabab fighters took control of the village. Three civilian villagers were abducted by al Shabaab fighters after the attack. The motive behind the abduction was not clear. There were no reports of casualties. Al Shabaab fighters withdrew from the locations of the incident. A second source claims government forces were involved.

21st November, PM, Jowhar, Middle Shabelle: Unconfirmed local reporting has stated that al Shabaab assailants threw a number of hand grenades into the property of a Hirshabelle member of parliament. The target's wife and bodyguard were injured.

Police and residents of Walmer township in Port Elizabeth have been in a tense standoff after protesters barricaded roads with burning tyres. Public order police responded with rubber bullets, stun grenades and tear gas.

actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: SPLA-IO claimed to have repulsed government attacks on their positions in various areas of Mayendit in Unity.

actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: Renewed clashes between government and SPLA-IO forces in Leer county over 21-22 November. Government claimed 20 rebels and five government soldiers were killed in the fighting, including 16 rebels and one government soldier in Leer town on 22 November. SPLA-IO spokesperson said government bombed their positions around Leer on 21 November and attacked them at Pawiny and Kaigai areas on 22 November, from where they were repulsed leaving 10 SPLA soldiers and two rebels killed.

Peace agreement: A peace declaration was signed between four Murle leaders and county commissionners at the Kuron peace village in Jonglei at a "historic peace and reconciliation conference" convened by UNMISS. The leaders vowed to improve the dire situation in the southeast region, resolving to address corruption and nepotism, the marginalization of minorities, cattle raiding and to improve relations with neighbouring communities. Date unclear - report dated 21 November.
10 armed herders opened fire on a group of farmers at Sagor area of Gireida in South Darfur, leaving one killed and one seriously injured.

source: Chimp Reports; The New Vision; The Observer
notes: Raid: on Tuesday 21st, Red Pepper's offices in Namanve were raided by Ugandan police forces. This came one day after Red Pepper published a story alleging that Rwanda believed President Yoweri Museveni was plotting to oust President Paul Kagame (with unnamed sources). The police department on Counter Terrorism ransacked the offices and 8 journalists were arrested. Computers and mobiles were confiscated and the houses of some journalists were searched.

When the resignation of Mugabe was announced, crowds flooded into the streets in Mutare to celebrate. Some of the crowds attacked and looted the Choppies supermarkets (owned by Vice President Mphoko). The military dispersed the looters.
Protesters gathered in Africa Unity Square to call for Mugabe's resignation and pray. When the resignation was announced, many more protesters joined, to celebrate the end of his presidency,

A civilian who had participated in celebrations of the resignation of Mugabe was accused of looting goods from Vice President Mphoko's shop, Choppies. The security guards handed him over to the military who detained him in the barracks and beat him.

assoc_actor_1: CNAPESTE: Autonomist National Council of High School and Technical School Teachers
notes: Teachers sit-in outside the Directorate of Education in Tizi Ouzou. The police roughly disperse the protesters.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: A police patrol was attacked around the area of Nongodoum, near the Mali border. Casualties unknown. The attack was later claimed by JNIM.
Women in Muyinga held a demonstration to protest against the release of a rapist. The police defended the state offices from the crowd of women.
5 dead and a dozen wounded in this morning's suicide bombing in Kolofata.
Strikes: On 20 November, a new  "dead-city" day was organized in Bamenda.

About 400 dismissed workers from Shebin Textile protested at the headquarters of the General Union of Spinning and Weaving.
A militant was killed and 18 other arrested by military forces during a clash in central Sinai.
Residents of Dima protest a local mining business deal which they believe will be economically ineffective.
Residents of Adola protest a local mining business deal which they believe will be economically ineffective. The date of the Adola protest is not known - source dated 20/11.
Defection: Thirty soldiers of the army's 10th division disappear along the southern border with Kenya. The group may have deserted.
Liyu police kill 30 people in 'northern Oromia,' reasons not known. Seven of the dead are Oromo.

notes: Two days of clashes between young protesters and police in Conakry over the state of education, which claimed the lives of two teenagers on Monday and Tuesday. At least 15 people were injured. Young people burned tires, dumped garbage cans and clashed with police with stones and slingshots.

Supporters of President Uhuru Kenyatta took to the streets in major towns in Kiambu County to celebrate the decision by the Supreme Court to uphold his October 26 election victory. The celebrations were witnessed in the towns of Kiambu, Thika, Gatundu, Limuru, Kikuyu, Banana, Githunguri and Wangige where residents, some donning Jubilee outfits marched to the streets while waving the Kenyan flag.

NTV and other leading TV stations also broadcast footage of large crowds in President Uhuru Kenyatta's strongholds in Rift Valley regions celebrating the Supreme Court ruling.

Supporters of President Uhuru Kenyatta took to the streets in major towns in Kiambu County to celebrate the decision by the Supreme Court to uphold his October 26 election victory. The celebrations were witnessed in the towns of Kiambu, Thika, Gatundu, Limuru, Kikuyu, Banana, Githunguri and Wangige where residents, some donning Jubilee outfits marched to the streets while waving the Kenyan flag.
Police have fired teargas to disperse crowds in Kisumu city to protest the Supreme Court's decision to uphold the 26 October repeat presidential poll. Protesters burned tyres on a road in the city.

Protesters took to the street in opposition areas in the capital and the west of the country against a court decision. A paramedic tending the injured at a demonstration in western Migori was shot dead.

Police  dispersed a crowd of protesters in the Korogocho settlement in the capital, Nairobi. Youths in Kawangware engaged in running battles with anti-riot police. One protester was killed in Nairobi's Kibera slum. Hundreds penetrated a police barrier and marched along the road wielding pangas, robbing people along the way and chanting their slogans.

Riot officers at the LNP raided protesters at UL on Monday during protest over the closure of registration process for the ongoing academic semester, arresting both prospective graduates and non- graduating students, with the protesters throwing objects at the campus-based police officers unequipped to withstand the level of violence.

On November 20, at least two migrants were killed and 13 others wounded in a traffic accident near Sirte when the driver lost control of the car carrying the migrants, allegedly after being pursued by the Misratah 166 militia.

Residents of Sabha protest and demand an increased security presence in Sabha. On the same day,doctors in Sabha hospital protest and strike after one of their members is kidnapped. It is unknown whether the kidnappers are a political or criminal armed group.
Villagers from the area of Senior Group Village Headman Kamwendo maliciously damaged property at the school.

People gathered to denounce the sale of human beings in Libya. The mobilization began with a sit-in in front of the Libyan Embassy in Bamako. Malians chained themselves to each other in front of the building with faded walls, in front of which was deployed a large cordon of policemen
Protesters in Casablanca demonstrate in solidarity with the 15 women killed in Sidi Boulaalam by a stampede during the distribution of supplies.
Protesters in Essaouria demonstrate in solidarity with the 15 women killed in Sidi Boulaalam by a stampede during the distribution of supplies.
Strike: the workers of the Mozambican Company of Tuna (EMATUM) are on strike since Monday 20th, owing to unpaid salaries for the duration of 4 months.
Looting: Several carriages of the group of radio and private television BonfÃ©reye, were ransacked in the night of Monday to Tuesday by an unknown group.

At least 30 people were killed when Bachama farmers attacked Fulani civilians in Kikan, Kodomun, Shafaran and Ketowal villages of Numan LGA. Fatalities vary; some witness claim 47, others 60. According to witnesses, this was the second attack by Bachama farmers this month against Fulanis in Adamawa. The date and the second location are not known. Fatalities divided between two events.

At least 30 people were killed when Bachama farmers attacked Fulani civilians in Kikan, Kodomun, Shafaran and Ketowal villages of Numan LGA. Fatalities vary; some witness claim 47, others 60. According to witnesses, this was the second attack by Bachama farmers this month against Fulanis in Adamawa. The date and the second location are not known.  Fatalities divided between two events.
Students from varying schools throughout Osun State protest in Oshogbo against a tuition hike. The protesters blocked roads and clashed with police.
Residents of Uhumnwonde Local Government Area protest at the Edo State House assembly over the suspension of their elected representative.
An APC chieftain is found dead with injuries to the head. Perpetrators not known.

Government forces launch a military campaign against al Shabaab in Sablaale, taking several villages under their control. Specific villages not named. There were no specific reports of violence, though the source implies some activity. Causalities not known. At the time of reporting the government forces were positioned at the outskirts of the Sablaale town. It was reported that al Shabaab had begun fleeing from Sablaale proper, but still held the town.
20th November, Galgala, Bari, Puntland: Puntland Security forces have claimed to have carried out further offensive operations against al Shabaab. Details limited.
Al Shabaab ambushed an SNA convoy between Balcad and Jowhar ivo Gololey. Two SNA troops reported killed in the attack.

Al Shabaab fighters conducted a hit-and-run attack against an SNA security checkpoint at Mukayga vicinity in Afgoye district. There was an exchange of heavy gunfire which lasted for about 25 minutes after which al Shabaab withdrew. One SNA soldier was injured. Al Shabaab casualties could not be ascertained at the time of reporting.
Hundreds of local residents conducted a peaceful demonstration in the area between Gaaca and Bossaso main market in protest to a construction company. The demonstration ended peacefully at 1140 hrs.

Unidentified armed militia shot and slightly injured a pastoralist from Saâad clan in Teerage area (c. 15 km South West of Galkayo). The attackers stole one camel from the victim and escaped from the area.
An alleged child rapist from Delft was assaulted by an angry mob on Monday after an 11-year-old girl was attacked.
In Harrismith, 1000 protesting community members spontaneously tipped over a police sedan and a bakkie that was parked nearby and set both alight.
Ten people were arrested for the alleged attempted murder of a sangoma in a vigilante attack. The sangoma was admitted to hospital.
Macassar residents went on a rampage, allegedly killing two murder suspects in mob justice attacks.

actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: SPLA-IO rebels claimed to have repulsed a pro-government forces' attack on their positions in Ayod county in Jonglei's Wau over 19-20 November, inflicting "heavy losses" Dozens were wounded on their side. Several local sources confirmed the fighting while the spokesperson of the South Sudanese army denied the clashes.

source: Sudan Tribune; Eye Radio; Daily Monitor
notes: Unknown gunmen ambushed two vehicles along the Nimule-Juba road at Nesitu town, including an Ugandan commercial vehicle, leaving the driver wounded.

Arrests: The community security police of Dongola in Sudanâs Northern state arrested 83 youths during the week of 20 November, most of them students, for âodd shaving and wearing inappropriate uniformsâ.
Two armed herders raped a young girl working on a farm in Daba Naira, north of Tawila, and stabbed to death her mother as she tried to intervene.

Policemen allegedly beat and tortured three herders from Rabak in Sudanâs White Nile State in detention. They were detained for 20 days on suspicion of stealing cattle. Date of arrest unclear - report dated 7 December.

On Monday evening, over 150 artisanal miners in Kishapu district invaded Williamson Diamond Ltd in attempt to forcefully take minerals. The security guards were attacked by the miners, known as Wabeshi, and started fighting them. One 20-year old man was killed and 2 security guards were injured. 6 people were arrested in connection to the event.

On Monday 20th, a group of people stormed the headquarters of the Central Bank in Kampala and demanded for the arrest and prosecution of the director for regulation and supervision, Ms Justine Bagyenda, before they were dispersed by police. Traffic flow was disrupted momentarily by the group, who held placards with messages such as âarrest Bagyenda, President Museveni arrest Bagyendaâ and tried to force their way into the premises. They fled when police arrived at the scene.
Protesters gathered in Africa Unity Square to call for Mugabe's resignation and pray.
Students at the University of Zimbabwe held a protest at which they proclaimed that they would refuse to write exams until President Mugabe had left office.
Al-Tassili's workers have been forced to protest because of the severe lack of safety conditions for passengers and the deteriorating working conditions for staff and pilots.
Unemployed youth sit-in to denounce their exclusion of the latest recruitment offers in the oil sector. The protesters were arrested by police.
Health worker assassinated overnight in the hamlet of BougÃ©l Kadje, area of Piladi about 20km north of Djibo, Soum Province.
Clashes between armed groups at the Mbopouloubou 75km from Alindao. No casualty toll available.

Extortion: The Mayi Mayi Charles Kakule stole 33 boat motors from the fishermen in Kyavinyonge, on Sunday 19th. They demanded 95.000 congolese francs in return for each motor. The motors were robbed because the fishermen had demanded to pay the weekly extortion of 15.000 francs that had previously been demanded. The Edward lake is surrounded by militias who are impeding the fishing activities.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: Extortion: Civil society in Ikobo, Walikale, claims that the military has since two weeks harassed civilians in the localities of Rusamambu and Muronga. Claims mention that barriers are been erected and that 500 francs are demanded each time in order to assess the camps in both localities. The claims mentions that militaries do not hesitate to demand payment of parts of crops and to torture civilians. The reports have been denied by the military.

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: A delegation from the political party Envol was preparing to hold a protest in Kenge, on the 19th, when police quickly intervened and dispersed them with tear gas. The report mentions that several persons were injured during the intervention. Another report mentions 6 severely injured by bullets, 2 by batons and more than 30 militants arrested.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: A clash between the FARDC and a coalition of Mayi Mayi Mazembe and Malaika took place on the 19th in the locality of Bashu, in Beni. 6 people died, of which 4 militiamen and 2 soldiers. 4 other militamen were injured. The coalition is said to be defending the Nande community.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: The city of Kilembwe fell, on the night of Sunday 19th, into the hands of the coalition between the Mayi Mayi Yakutumba and Malaika. The FARDC retreated to 20km from the city in order to avoid a bloodbath. The coalition militia attacked the FARDC offices in Kilembwe, killing one soldier. The city of Kilembwe is strategic due to its proximity to the mining site of society Banro, in Namoya. With the taking of this village, the Yakutumba control 80% of the Lulimba-Kilembwe route.
Clashes erupted in Nairobi's Mathare slum on Sunday after four bodies were found in the street, with outrage spreading to Kibera.
On November 19, opposition supporters engaged police in running battles in many parts of Nairobi as they protested the killing of five people by Mungiki.

On November 19, eleven people were allegedly killed in Baba Dogo, Nairobi. Local residents blamed the killing of at least five people on Mungiki. Raila Odinga accused the government of orchestrating the attacks.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States
notes: The US military launch an airstrike against IS militants in Furqaha. No mention of casualties.

admin1: Tajura wa an Nawahi al Arba
notes: On 19 November, branches of Janzur and Taghura of the Department of Combating Illegal Immigration broke into a temporary camp for migrants in the Mayan area, to arrest smugglers and other criminal elements. The use of firearms reportedly killed one and injured four others among male migrants.

People of Tamanhint protest and demand the reopening of the airport to connect the city with the rest of the country. The demonstrators argue that isolation is leading to the region being left behind. At the same time, protesters demonstrate against the video of slave auctions on Libya's coast.
Guide of FAMa's anti-poaching brigade assassinated at his home in Hombori.
Boko Haram attacks Lawati village in Jere, kills six.

Many members of the opposition Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) in Kwara state protested in Ilorin, state capital to protest allegations of electoral frauds perpetrated by the ruling All Progressive Congress(APC) in the concluded local governments elections conducted at the weekend. Police made arrests.
Boko Haram insurgents have  beheaded six farmers at Dimge plantation, in Mafa Local Government Area of Borno State. Seven others were abducted.
Pensioners protest over unpaid arrears in Owerri.
Unidentified assassins kill three at the compound of the Commissioner of Local Government and Chieftaincy Affairs.
Unidentified gunmen assassinate the village head of Tarangol community.
At least one government soldier was reported wounded in a gun attack on a Somali security checkpoint in Wardhigley. Al Shabaab claimed responsibility. The Somali memo claims three dead.
Al Shabaab carried out a drive-by shooting against SNG forces. One soldier killed, three wounded.

actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: Government claimed SPLA-IO attacked their positions in Rubkuei in Leer, southern Liech state on 19 November.

actor1: SPLA/M-In Opposition-Deng Gai: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition (Deng Gai Faction)
notes: Defection: A senior member of the SPLM-IO led by FVP Taban Deng Gai (Brig Gen. Charles Wani) resigned from his position, accusing the latter of contributing to the escalation of war in the country. Wani had joined the Deng Gai faction after SPLA-IO leader Riek Machar fled Juba in July 2016.

Arrests: Authorities in Akop County in Warrap arrested more than 150 members of the Seventh-day Adventist Church over 18-19 November. Residents complained that the Church attracted a large number of local residents compared to other denominations.

Government forces severely beat and opened fire on a group of people in Tullus and El Salam localities in South Darfur while carrying out the disarmament campaign on or around 19 November, leaving two killed and six injured. It is unclear if the people were armed and violent at the time of the incident.
Gunmen opened fire on a farmer working in Farok area north of Kutum in North Darfur, killing him instantly, on or around 19 November. The motive of the shooting is unclear.

During an anti-cattle raid on Sunday, the UPDF killed a 23 year old student in Katakwi District. The student was mistaken by a cattle hustler. When asked for ID, he ran away and was shot by the soldiers on the head.

assoc_actor_2: MDC-T: Movement for Democratic Change (Tsvangirai Faction)
notes: An MDC-T activist was beaten by soldiers in Mbare. He tried to report the case but the police refused to record it.
Workers of the Sidi Bellabas plantation protested over the delay in payment of their wages for four months.
Protesters went to the street to demand the acceleration and a judgment in favor of General Gilbert DiendÃ©rÃ©, arrested since October 30, 2015 following the failed coup d'etat.

A man in Masango was killed over a land dispute.

A policeman was wounded in the night from Saturday to Sunday at the main food market in Bamenda, by two motorcycle individuals who opened fire on a patrol. A 23-year-old civilian was accidentally shot by policemen and died in hospital on Monday. The same night, at least three civilians were injured by the police, two of them shot, according to concordant sources.
Delta textile workers in Tanta have been protesting in solidarity with 25 of their colleagues who were referred to investigation because they demanded payment of outstanding salaries.
Head of Egyptâs Central Security Forces and other police personnel survived an assassination attempt by an Improvised Explosive Device (IED).

In west Hararge, Daro Labu woreda, Ethiopian security forces wearing Liyu police uniforms killed two people by cutting their reproductive organs and their heads. The reason for the attack is not known.
In Bale zone, Gindir woreda, Liyu police reportedly killed children gathering firewood. No further information on causality figures.

A newly formed militant group known as the 'Ethiopian National Party' carries out two attacks on military forces in Gonder and Azezo. No causalities reported. The political goals of the group are not yet known.

A newly formed militant group known as the 'Ethiopian National Party' carries out two attacks on military forces in Gonder and Azezo. No causalities reported. The political goals of the group are not yet known.

Some residents of the Volta Region poured onto the streets of the Regional Capital, Ho, to protest against government with the claim that the region is being left out in the execution of development projects by the new government.
The body of a family member the former Qaddafi-era Benghazi governor has been found near Saloug, south-west of the city.

actor1: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction

Fokonolona members killed 2 suspected criminals in_Besaboha, Andrevorevo,_Analalava.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims

The population of Mossurize is being subjected to a climate of fear perpetrated by Renamo armed men. According to reports, the armed men are accosting civilians, extorting them and stealing from them. The situation is ongoing.

Thousands of Zimbabweans residing in Namibia marched to that country's embassy in Windhoek in solidarity with demonstrations throughout the region in support of the removal of president Robert Mugabe.
Three Boko Haram suicide bombers (two detonated) attack Maiduguri on 18/11, killing two (plus two bombers). Xinhua claims five dead and four wounded.

Boko Haram suicide bombers attack Alakaramtii village of Jere LGA in two waves. The bombers were teen-aged females. The first came in the "wee" hours of the day, the second at 0600hrs. The one of the bombers in the second pair took off her vest and placed in next to a house before fleeing. At least four dead, including the three bombers.
A vigilante mob attacks and lynches two over alleged motorcycle theft.

Two suspected members of the Indigenous People of Biafra (IPOB) were attacked by a "mob" and later arrested by the police in Anambra East after it was suspected they planned to disrupt an election. It is believed the pair were first attacked by a 'mob.'

18th November, AM, Geed Faqi, Lower Shabelle: Reports have stated that al Shabaab have retaken a settlement called Geed Faqay sat approximately 14km South West of Balcad. Incidents of violence not known.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States
notes: Troop deployment: The United States (US) Pentagon announced over 500 US soldiers were currently deployed in Somalia. It was not reported when the soldiers were deployed. The announcement coincides with increased US air attacks in the recent period.

Hundreds of Zimbabweans of all creeds and races took to the streets of Johannesburg to celebrate what they hope is the imminent departure of President Robert Mugabe who is under pressure from the military and the ruling party to resign.
Unknown gunmen killed the son of the tribal chief in Cuei chok area in Western Lakes state.
Citizens and civil society activists organised a protest in Sfax against the installation of a statue of former president Habib Bourguiba. They claim that Bourguiba marginalised Sfax in his projects.
Civil Society acctivists protested in front of the municipial theater against a controversial security law which stipulates high penalties for resisting and attacking security forces.

On Saturday 18th, the Rubabo County MP Mary Paula Turyahikayo was forced to stop an age consultation meeting after a group of rowdy youth disrupted it. The incident happened at Kayanga Primary School in Kisiizi and the group prevented the MP from continuing her address, forcing her to leave in order to avoid chaos.

notes: Thousands of people marched peacefully in Bulawayo to call for Mugabe to step down.

notes: Hundreds of thousands of protesters marched peacefully in Harare to call on Mugabe to step down.
A resident of Kuwadzana was returning from the anti-Mugabe march, when he was confronted by 4 men who beat him severely. They told him that Mugabe was the only leader of Zimbabwe.

About twenty Ansaroul Islam militants raided the village of Ariel, Soum Province near the Malian border around 20h, the militants fired in the air and abducted two villagers.

Locals of Shakiso protest a contract extension of a 'billionaire' mining gold in the area.

A bomb thrown into a hotel in Bahir Dar injured two people. The grenade was thrown into the Yohannes II Garden Hotel where a soccer team from Axum, Tigray had checked in. It is not known if the team was the target.
At least ten people were killed and several others wounded in an attack at Ziway that sources say might have an 'ethnic element.'

At least five people were killed Friday in confrontations between Kenyan police and supporters of opposition leader Raila Odinga as tensions over the disputed presidential election continued. Rioters are deemed responsible of many acts of violence, inculding sexual violence and property desruption. Eyewitnesses said police shot them. "There were 15 bodies at the City mortuary and three at Chiromo mortuary when we visited. These people were shot by the gun and cartridges collected,â claimed Raila

The President of the Niono District Court was abducted by unknown gunmen in Niono.
"Thugs" attack PDP members and supporters at Kwall Stadium, venue of an upcoming election. Injuries reported.

Unidentified gunmen attacked a group of soldiers guarding a storage facility operated by Royal Dutch Shell and British Petroleum in Port-Harcourt. One soldier dead. The reason for the attack is not known.
Farmers and suspected Fulanis clash in Bakoshi, Suru LGA. It is believed the farmers instigated the clash. Area police made several arrests. At least one death.

Villagers of Sabuwar Gayan in Chikun Local Government of Area of Kaduna State blocked the Kaduna-Abuja highway, protesting the killing of the Commander of Civilian JTF Haruna Halilu in their community by suspected kidnappers. The situation caused heavy gridlock as both lanes of the road were blocked for two hours.
3,000 retired primary school teachers, under the umbrella of the National Union of Pensioners (NUP) in Oyo State protested non-payment of their 17-56 months pension arrears.
A cameraman with the Anambra Broadcasting Service (ABS), Mr Ikechukwu Onubogu, has been found dead four days after he was declared missing. The date of death and perpetrators not known.
Unknown gunmen killed the communications' director of the South Sudanâs Relief and Rehabilitation Commission (RRC) at his residence  in Juba.

Thousands of opponents of Faure Gnassingbe's regime demonstrated in Togo for the second consecutive day Friday, demonstrating once again that popular mobilization does not falter after three months of political crisis, said an AFP correspondent.

A woman farmer in Mazowe was beaten by soldiers who were trying to evict her from her farm. When she resisted they beat her.
The head of the prefecture of Cheira was injured by a candidate from the PLJ-party who suspects the head of privileging another party for municipal elections without remaining impartial.
High school students who were protesting violence by Koglweogos against a fellow student beat Koglweogos in TiÃ©bÃ©lÃ© commune. The students wanted to avenge one of their comrades.
A former soldier was ambushed and attacked by unidentified assailants in Masango. The attackers accused him of hoarding grenades.
Arrests: Abba Goroma alias Abba Adam alias Alhadji Hassan, former commander of Banki and Kumshe sectors, was arrested on November 16, in Kodek with four of his bodyguards and transferred to Yaounde.
Propert destruction: School destroyed in Hodogo on the night of November 16
Clashes between armed groups since November 16th, on the Bria Ippy axis.
Egypt's armed forces said that they have killed three "high-level" suspected militants and arrested 74 others in sweeps in the troubled northern Sinai Peninsula in recent days.

Students in Bule Hora University demonstrated against national security forces on campus.

notes: Security forces dispersed with grenades, a march organized in Bissau by a group of 18 opposition political parties, while the demonstrators were a few meters from the Presidential Palace. The repression of the march that has gathered thousands of people, has made at least nine wounded, including three serious, according to the organizers.

Kenyatta University has been closed indefinitely following a night of riots by students. There are reports that a huge fire broke out in one of the buildings in the institution.The University's Vice Chancellor Prof Paul Wainaina announced on Friday morning that the decision was prompted by the ongoing lecturers' strike that had " heightened agitation among students".

Embakasi East MP Babu Owino, his Rauaraka counterpart TJ Kajwang and Starehe politician Steve Mbogo were arrested Thursday as Opposition leaders engaged police in a cat-and-mouse game. The leaders were apprehended on Ngongâ Road as they attempted to enter Kibraâs Kamkunji ground where NASA had scheduled a rally that had been banned by the police.

Three bandits who were caught and killed by the local community in a case of mob justice in Ambatoriha-Est.
Police broke up a sit-in protest of slum dwellers. The protesters were demonstrating against a forced eviction of their waterfront homes.
Students of Obafemi Awolowo University protested in Oshogbo over "exploitation" by the school's management.
Protests following a military-led criminal raid on Peremabiri. The protesters perceived the military action as an invasion.
Pensioners protest over unpaid arrears.
Al Shabaab launches grenade attack against Heliwa district police HQ. Causalities, damage not known.
Al Shabaab attacks a government military checkpoint in Yaaqshiid. The government forces rebuffed the attack and made 10 arrests. No reported causalities.
Al Shabaab attacked a government checkpoint at Hawa Abdi. Causalities not known.

Waddani Party supporters on 16/11 took to the streets of various opposition strongholds (locations not provided) to protest what they claim to be election irregularities. In Burco police had to use live bullets to disperse protestors who had lit bonfires and closed main roads. No reported injuries.
16th November, 1100L, Heliwa, Mogadishu: A local elder was shot and killed by two gunmen in a likely targeted killing. Perpetrators not known.
Wadani Party supporters, alleging voter rigging, clash with police and light fires. No reported causality.
Wadani Party supporters, alleging voter rigging, clash with police and light fires. One death reported. A second source claims 3 dead.
Police have used stun grenades to disperse peaceful protesters in Steenberg, Cape Town.
Unknown gunmen ambushed a commercial vehicle between Malou and Bangacharot in Bor South, Jonglei, killing a top-ranking army officer and injuring six civilians.

Agreement: SPLM factions signed a âDeclaration of Unificationâ to rebuild trust and confidence among them in Cairo, Egypt under the auspices of the Egyptian President al-Sisi and his Ugandan counterpart Museveni. SPLM-IO led by Machar was excluded from the deal.
Unknown gunmen killed a businessman in a targeted killing in Torit.
Unknown gunmen ambushed a motorcyclist between Malou and Bangacharot in Bor south in Jonglei, leaving him injured.

Thousands of opponents of Faure Gnassingbe's regime demonstrated once again that popular mobilization does not falter after three months of political crisis, said an AFP correspondent.

Social housing beneficiaries organised a protest in front of the seat of the wilaya in Bouira to demand a swift completion of guaranteed social housing unitis.

An altercation occurred between villagers and a Chinese worker, who took a homemade gun and shot a villager dead. The local population reacted with pebbles, pickaxes, and clubs to fight the Chinese man who was also killed. The anger of local populations did not stop at the death of the Chinese, they also administered a caning to all Chinese nationals of the yard.
Clashes between armed groups on the Dimbi-Langandi axis. Several dead and 10 wounded.

One person was killed and one wounded in the attack of armed men against a market in the Chadian town of Koulbous. After looting the market, killing one person and wounding another, the attackers retreated to Sudan.

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)

notes: Arrests: Police in the Democratic Republic of Congo made several dozen arrests to stifle protests. LUCHA mentions at least 27 civilians were arrested in Nord-Kivu, including 15 in Goma. 13 other activists were detained while a communique was being read in the province of Sud-Kivu. The government confirms 19 arrests, comprising six in Goma, seven in Lubumbashi and six in Matadi. The Human Rights division of MONUSCO notes that there were arbitrary arrests taking place during the day, notably in Goma and Kinshasa. Human Rights Watch mentions that at least 52 people were arrested while protesting in Goma, Kasindi, Kindu, Kisangani, Kinshasa, and Idjwi.

actor2: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: In Idjwi, on Wednesday 15th, protesters took to the streets responding to a call from other citizens movements and civil society groups to demonstrate their opposition towards the published electoral calendar and demand that President Joseph Kabila leave office by the end of 2017. The police responded aggressively, beating the protesters and arresting some of them. Among them, there is a report by a 15 year old girl who was likewise assaulted by police.

notes: The Mayi Mayi attacked the prison of Kakwangura in Butembo on November 15th as an attempt to free their relatives. The FARDC quickly intervened and halted the assault. The death toll resulted in 3 militiamen killed and one civilian injured. The escape of prisoners was halted by FARDC's intervention.

actor2: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: Four people were injured during clashes with the police on Wednesday 15th. Although it started as a peaceful protest, police clashed with protesters, firing live bullets. Accounts differ on the motivations for the protest. On the one side, it is said that protesters were students demanding the resume of their classes; their teachers had been in strike for a week due to their unpaid salaries. On the other end, the protesters are said to be part of a civilian movement in Lusambo to denounce the mismanagement of Governor Berthold Ulungu.
Unknown people set a bus on fire in Lubumbashi on the 15th, in the same day that a strike by civilians was called in protest of the announcement of the electoral calendar.

Eritrean refugees and opposition groups staged a protest against their government, specifically against political and religious persecution. The protesters numbered 200.
Liyu police killed one Oromo man in Adama and sexually assaulted his wife.

The Northern Regional Security Council (REGSEC), has beefed up security in the troubled Yunyoo enclave of the Bunkprugu/Yunyoo district. This followed sporadic gunshots  over the siting of the capital for the yet to be created Yunyoo District.

Property destruction: Nomadic herdsmen have allegedly burnt down nine homes in the Kwahu East in the Eastern region as conflict with farmers continues. Hundreds have been reportedly displaced after the Wednesday night attack.

Property destruction: A church at the centre of a land tussle was destroyed on 15 November at Jogoo area in Kisii Town. Church officials said hired goons descended on Millennium SDA Church and vandalised it.

Students and riot officers of the Liberian National Police clashed on the Fendell Campus of the University of Liberia. The riot began when thousands of students were reportedly denied by authorities of the university to complete their registration process.

A clash between two families over land in Misratah results in 7 deaths.

Workers aligned to the Mineworkers Union of Namibia (MUN) staged a peaceful protest at the mine's head office at the coastal town of Swakopmund, where they handed a petition to the company's management.
Workers of the Nigerian Institute of Mining and Geo-sciences (NIMG), Jos on 15/11 staged a peaceful protest against alleged mismanagement of the outfit by its Chief Executive Officer.
Ijaw and Urhobo residents of Ogbe-Ijoh, Isaba and Aladja clash on 15/11. A total of three dead, twenty injured. The clash is believed to be related to land use.

Ijaw and Urhobo residents of Ogbe-Ijoh, Isaba and Aladja clash on 15/11. A total of three dead, twenty injured. The clash is believed to be related to land use.

Bachama farmers attack Fulani civilians in Adamawa State. This was the first of two such attacks. The second took place in Numan later in the month. The date and location of the first attack is not known. Causalities likely.

Boko Haram attacks Sabon Gari and Kafin Hausa on the night of 15/11. The attackers killed many livestock, and looted and burnt many houses before they were repelled by security forces. No reported deaths. The attackers were repelled by soldiers, hunters and members of the local vigilante.

Boko Haram attacks Sabon Gari and Kafin Hausa on the night of 15/11. The attackers killed many livestock, and looted and burnt many houses before they were repelled by security forces. No reported deaths. The attackers were repelled by soldiers, hunters and members of the local vigilante.
Non-academic staff of the University of Obafemi Awolowo University protest payments "in November."
Hundreds of residents of Otodo-Gbame community gathered at the  Lagos State Governor's Office, Alausa, to protest against their forced eviction from their riverine community.
Four suicide bombers attack the Muna area, killing twelve civilians (this figure was later raised to 18, plus 29 injured), including themselves.

Al Shabaab fighters fired six mortar shells against Puntland forces at Af-Urur village of Galgala mountain (c. 70 km South West of Bossaso). There were no reports of causalities.

Following the barrage, al Shabaab forces attack the village with small-arms fire, but were rebuffed by the AMISOM forces. Causalities not known from the small-arms exchange.
A civilian is killed in a clan motivated affairs. Identities not known.

A civilian man from Ayr sub-clan of Habargidir was shot and killed by clan militias from Ali sub-clan of Hawdle clan at Qabno area (c. 38 km North of Beletweyne). Another fellow clan member who was with the victim managed to escape from the scene. The vehicle that was driven by the victim was taken by the militia. The incident was related to a retaliation of a previous killing of a man from Hawadle clan at Mataban district by Habargidir clan.
Over 800 marchers belonging to various associations affiliated to the Eastern Cape Liquor Forum in Beacon Bay submitted a memorandum demanding transparency and answers in 14 days.

Two aid workers were killed by unidentified gunmen in Awerial, Lakes state, in November.

The protesters moved into another nearby area and continued their chants.
Taxi drivers protested in Medenine against the municipality tipping construction waste at their taxi station.

Students protested in front of the seat of the prefecture in Medenine after being deprived of the right to an internship in the final phase of their studies. Moreover, parents of pupils from a school in Medenine protested against lacking teaching personel in the school.

Police used live bullets and teargas to quell a violent strike by students at Ndorwa Muslim Secondary School in Southern Division in Kabale Municipality. Students started pelting their teachers with stones and destroyed windowpanes in several classrooms.The anti-riot police fired live bullets and used tear gas to disperse the riot.
Defusal: A bomb was disarmed by the bomb squad and the police, who were called to inverne, at Kampala Jinja Highway  on Wendesday 15th.
When military forces arrived to arrest Finance Minister Ignatius Chombo, his security guards opened fire, causing a shoot-out. 3 guards were killed.
Arrests: The military of Zimbabwe placed President Mugabe under house arrest and took control of the government.

Property destruction: The military raided the homes of Ministers Kasukuwere and Moyo during the military take-over. The soldiers fired shots and destroyed property.
