notes: Between 1 and 2 November, government and SPLA-IO forces clashed in Kotobi and Yeri near the town of Mundri, Western Equatoria, leading to civilian displacement.

Herders shot dead a resident of Kassab IDP camp in Kutum locality, North Darfur, as he resisted when they tried to take his grain at his farm at Jumbo area north of the camp. Incidents have reportedly increased since the herders have been driven out of Kutum by the RSF.
A young man, reportedly inspired by Islamist extremism, stabbed two policemen in front of the Tunisian parliament before being arrested. One of the two policemen later died from his injuries..

Policemen demonstrated in front of the hospital in which an injured policeman died after an attack the day before. Protesters demand that parliament adopt a law on "protecting" them against unlawful attacks.
Arrests: 72 villagers were arrested by police during a mass eviction on Fox Farm in Matobo.
Hundreds of Seventh Day Adventist youths marched through the streets of Chitungwiza to protest drug abuse.
Manzou villagers fought running battles with the police who had come again to attempt to evict them from land claimed by Grace Mugabe.

Angry villagers in Silobela rioted and chased away the ZANU PF MP, who they accused of attempting to interfere with the distribution of government-sourced agricultural inputs. He later returned with the Riot Police to control the situation.
Property destruction: 200 settlers were left homeless when security forces, acting under the instructions of JOC, burned down a settlement at Yorkshire C7 Farm, in Headlands.

actor1: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
notes: ZANU-PF militia attacked and beat 5 people at a farm in Chinhoyi. There is a struggle between the senior ZANU-PF official who moved onto the farm during the land invasions and a new ZANU-PF official who is trying to occupy the farm more recently. The labourers were hired by one of the claimants, and were beaten by supporters of the other claimant.
A police officer beat a vendor in the Harare CBD. The police officer falsely accused the vendor of assaulting a police officer.

Hundreds of workers from Cevital factory organized a massive march towards Bejaia. The march ended with a protest rally during which the activists of the Cevital Workers Support Committee protested against austerity measures by the authorities.

Students from the English department at the University Mouloud Mammeri in Tizi Ouzou (Hasnaoua) staged a sit-in which blocked access to the directorate and administrative offices of their department to protest against the ignorance of the administration regarding sexual harrassment cases.
GFAT vehicle struck by IED at 9h near Ariel (Nassoumbou), close to Mali border, 3 soldiers wounded.

When Cankuzo police tried to clear a group of soldiers from Mutukura Camp out of a Cankuzo bar, the soldiers retaliated, resulting in violent clashes. The police chief dispersed the crowd by firing into the air, and then the police pursued the soldiers back to the camp.

actor1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: Imbonerakure beat a student in Murwi and sliced the veins in his arm because they saw him walking home with a bag of cassava, which they accused him of stealing.
2 people killed yesterday night at Mada II.

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
source: Goma; Agence France Presse; Daily Nation
notes: Police in Beni said they had arrested nine demonstrators during a march Tuesday against President Joseph Kabila, a day after clashes in the region that left five dead. All nine were reportedly from LUCHA and protesting in the public highway without authorisation. A LUCHA campaigner stated that the police intervened shortly after the protest started, manhandling the protesters. 9 people from LUCHA were arrested by the police.

Egypt's air force had carried out a desert raid west of Fayoum that killed a large number of militants responsible for the deaths of 16 policemen earlier this month. Police Forces attacked the militants and freed a kidnapped police officer after the air-raids.

Egypt's air force had carried out a desert raid west of Fayoum that killed a large number of militants responsible for the deaths of 16 policemen earlier this month. Police Forces attacked the militants and freed a kidnapped police officer after the air-raids.
The Egyptian armed forces announced the destruction of six four-wheel-drive vehicles loaded with ammunition and weapons near the Libyan border.
Four civilians have been killed when a mortar shell fired by militants hit their tractor in Al-Arish. A fifth civilian was wounded.

source: Red Sea Afars Democratic Organisation; Madote; Hagerawi Dihnet
notes: Following the government-imposed forced closure of an Islamic school in Asmara students and residents protest the action. A few of the demonstrators allegedly threw stones and brandished weapons at security forces according to pro-government media, while the government forces fired shots in the air to disperse the protesters. Dozens were arrested several. An activist group claimed that 28 people were killed and over 100 injured during the protest. However, this information was not verified in the following weeks and Information Minister Yemane Gebremeskel dismissed the reports of casualties.
Nine Amharas are dead following an attack by TPLF forces in Kamashi Zone. Many others were reportedly displaced.

Shop Owners of the Ashaiman Timber Market say they will resist all attempts to demolish their machines shops sited in an area recently re designated as part of the Tema Akosombo railway. The protest, which took the form of a sit down strike, had the cargo drivers and wood dealers, wearing red bands and refusing to attend to customers who had come to buy wood products
A rumour about the death of President Alpha Conde has resulted in a violent clash between gendarmes and journalists. 12  journalists were injured, their equipment and objects damaged.

2 journalists  were assaulted by youth during a NASA Parliamentary Group meeting at the Wiper headquarters in Nairobi. The journalist, who had already been verbally assaulted before the attack, were singled out due to working for Citizen, NTV, KBC and therefore were seen as being biased and leaning towards the re-election of the President Uhuru Kenyatta. Mr. Gachuri was forcedully evicted while Mrs. Gatwiri was slapped in the face.

Transport along Kericho-Kisumu Highway on Tuesday was disrupted after matatu owners blocked the road near Parkmatt supermarket protesting vandalism of their two vehicles. Anti-riot police fired teargas to disperse the protesters. Some vehicle passengers were injured in the process. The vehicles were allegedly vandalised near Chemelil trading center in Kisumu County by NASA supporters who were protesting the announcement of Uhuru Kenyatta as the winner of repeat presidential election.
The funeral of 15 civilians who died in airstrikes the day before turned into a demonstration, with slogans denouncing the bombing of innocent women and children.

actor1: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
notes: A civilian was injured as he stepped on a landmine in Ganfouda, Benghazi.

actor1: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
notes: Saiqa-special forces clashed with elements of the Islamic State in the Sidra area west of Ajdabiya without causing any casualties.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: One of the vehicles sent to rescue an MP was struck by an IED on the way back. 5 soldiers dead.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
actor2: MAA: Arab Movement of the Azawad (CMA)
notes: MAA military chief Heyba Ould Zeyn abducted by JNIM commando this afternoon at the market in Zouera, Tombouctou Region.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: Tenenkou MP/High Court president Niang was ambushed by JNIM men between DiafarabÃ© & Dia. The driver was killed in the ambush.
Hundreds of artisans on 31/10 stormed the Lagos State House of Assembly to protest demolition of their buildings in the state by the state government.

An armed al Shabaab fighter shot a municipal soldier at Weydow village in Deynile district. The soldier shot at the al Shabaab man killing him on the scene. The soldier later died of sustained injuries. Security forces responded to the incident and took the bodies of the soldier and al Shabaab operator. Al Shabaab militants claimed responsibility for the killing.

South West State (SWS) forces ambushed al Shabaab fighters near Jiiro Gurey area (c. 8 km South East of Berdaale) on the road between Baidoa and Berdaale. There was a brief exchange of gunfire after which South West State forces retreated from the scene and returned to their base at Berdaale (c. 55 km North West of Baidoa). One SWS soldier was injured and two al Shabaab fighters were killed in the attack. Al Shabaab fighters were reported to be headed to Buulo Xaawo village (c. 60 km West of Baidoa and c. 20 km South West of Berdaale).
Supporters of Wadani and Kulmiye political parties clashed in Bixin village (c. 30 km North West of El-Afweyn). Eight people were arrested in connection to the incident.

Biyo-maal armed clan militia attacked farmers and herdsmen from Mohamed Muse sub clan of Abgaal at KM 50 settlement in Afgoye district. There was an exchange of gunfire. The attack was as a result of clan feuds in the area. At least five persons were killed in the clan skirmish.

actor1: AMISOM: African Union Mission in Somalia (2007-)
notes: Local unconfirmed reporting has stated that the AMISOM base in Qooryoley had been attacked by al Shabaab. At present details remain limited.

actor1: AMISOM: African Union Mission in Somalia (2007-)
notes: An IED planted along the road, targeting an AMISOM convoy travelling at Maryan Gubay in Barawe district, exploded. One AMISOM vehicle was damaged by the explosion. Al Shabaab claimed responsibility for the attack. Additional reports stated that another IED exploded at a convoy in the area which was not far from the site of the first explosion.

A civilian male was shot and killed by an SNA soldier at Tarbuunka neighbourhood in Hodan district. The motive of the killing was based on a land dispute. One civilian female bystander was also injured. The perpetrator managed to escape.

A businessman hailing from Galjecel clan was abducted by Agoon sub-clan of Hawadle clan at Qabno (c. 38 km North of Beletweyne town). The incident was related to clan retaliation. Caafi sub-clan of Galjecel clan abducted four civilians from Agoon sub-clan of Hawadle clan in response to the abduction of the businessman. Efforts from influential clan elders were reported to be ongoing to defuse tension and secure the release of the abducted.

A businessman hailing from Galjecel clan was abducted by Agoon sub-clan of Hawadle clan at Qabno (c. 38 km North of Beletweyne town). The incident was related to clan retaliation. Caafi sub-clan of Galjecel clan abducted four civilians from Agoon sub-clan of Hawadle clan in response to the abduction of the businessman. Efforts from influential clan elders were reported to be ongoing to defuse tension and secure the release of the abducted.
Al Shabaab militants abducted a religious sufi-cleric man at Caad village (c. 30 km North of Harardheere).
Detonation: An al Shaabab IED detonates prematurely in Bossaso. No causalities.

actor1: AMISOM: African Union Mission in Somalia (2007-) (Uganda)
notes: IED detonates against UPDF convoy en route to MIA. 1 Civilian vehicle hit, 1 injured.
Following the abduction of a businessman from Galjacel, government forces clashed with Hawadle-Agoon militia. Two deaths reported.
Parents of pupils from Uitzig High School in Elsies River barricaded the provincial Education Departmentâs metro offices, following the announcement that the school will be shut down next month.

Supporters of Imam Nazeem Taliep, of Ghiedmatiel Islamia Mosque in Taronga Road, Crawford, picketed outside there in opposition to what they have characterised as persecution by the board of trustees.

A hospital in Vosloorus came under scrutiny after footage emerged showing security guards clashing with police officers during a strike at the hospital. The guards were protesting after they pitched at work only to be told that their services had been terminated and that another company had secured the contract.

actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: SPLA-IO claimed to have regained Ombasi on 2 November after around a week of clashes. The rebels claimed to have regained control of the area. They allegedly launched the attack after South Sudanese security officials denied civilians access to humanitarian assistance in Lasu payam.

Dozens of angry West Darfur farmers gathered in front of the office of the Commissioner of Sirba locality to demand compensation for damage they claim was caused to their harvest by herders' livestock. The commissioner denied any damage.
Four gunmen attacked two brothers on their way from camp Kalma to camp El Salam near Nyala to visit relatives; one was shot dead; the other's hand was cut-off.

actor2: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-) National Guard
notes: National Guard officer (corporal) wounded by mine/IED explosion at Jebel es-Sif (Foussana), Kasserine near Algeria border.
Retired policemen gathered in front of the House of Representatives to protest against irregularities during their professional career and exclusion from an agreement to iron out the irregularities.
A police commander was stabbed in the neck and killed by an "Islamist extremist" in Tunis.
Students at the Copperbelt University staged a peaceful protest after being left out of bursary schemes. The Riot Police attacked the students and arrested 55 of them. They were held for four days.

assoc_actor_1: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
notes: Jah Prayzah, a musician believed to be aligned to a ZANU PF faction, was chased and manhandled by mourners at a funeral, who are believed to be aligned to the other ZANU PF faction.

assoc_actor_1: NAVUZ: National Vendors Union of Zimbabwe
notes: The police attempted to block a Vendors' Union meeting in the Harare cathedral, but were chased away by the angry vendors.

assoc_actor_1: NAVUZ: National Vendors Union of Zimbabwe
notes: There were running battles between the police and the newspaper vendors in Gweru.

actor1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
actor2: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: The deputy head of the Mishiha Imbonerakure was beaten up in a bar by other senior provincial Imbonerakure and then arrested. He was told that the assault was punishment for not carrying out his duties correctly, but it is believed to have been because the head of the Mishiha Imbonerakure wants to replace him.
The head of the Port and Rail Maritime Authority in Rumonge was beaten by police officers when they realised that he was filming them taking bribes from merchants in the port.
At least 11 villagers slaughtered last night in Gouderi
A man was killed in Lakouanga neighbourhood by armed group's men.

actor2: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: The Mayi Mayi militia conducted by leader Luc Yabili clashed with the FARDC in Loya.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
assoc_actor_1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
notes: Violent clashes broke out in Beni between the FARDC, supported by MONUSCO, and the ADF in Beni, over attempts to gain the control of the route that connects Kamango to surrounding localities. At least one rebel was killed. 3 soldiers were wounded and 1 is missing.

actor2: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: A protest turned violent in Goma. Protesters, responding to a call from LUCHA, were demonstrating against the decision of the national election commission to hold off on elections to replace Kabila until April 2019. Activists had called for a general strike, but unrest broke out at 5am. Rioters barricaded streets and burned tires. One report mentions that rioters started attacking with knives, achetes, spears, arrows. Security forces killed at least 4 civilians and 1 police officer also died. Another report mentions that the police confirms 2 deaths, while witnesses confirm 6. The police station of Majengo was also completely ransacked before being set on fire. In Ndosho neighbourhood, the rioters held their barricades for 5 hours before the FARDC being called in to help.

Three are dead and several others wounded in Nekemt after rumours of an illegally owned firearm by a civilian. Two of the dead are Amhara and one is Oromo. It is believed the protests are related to the wider unrest in the region. Other 2 fatalities recorded in event on 29/10.

Some men believed to be supporters of the governing New Patriotic Party (NPP) have stormed the Techiman office of the National Disaster Management Organisation (NADMO) to sack the staff on duty. The men reportedly told the workers to go home because there is a new government in place, Joy News Brong Ahafo Regional Correspondent Anas Sabit said.
A religious chief was killed by an individual of TelemelÃ© province.
Police dispersed Jubilee supportes in Mumias.

In Kisumu, angry youth held demonstrations in Kondele, the main bus station and Nairobi Road complaining about the 866 votes said to have been cast in Kisumu. They lit bonfires, blocked roads and, in some cases, extorted money from motorists.

In Nairobi, several groups of supporters marched through the city's main streets singing and chanting to celebrate the win of newly-confirmed President Kenyatta. The same happened in other locations. In Narok, however, two men from different communities clashed, leaving 5 people injured.
In the slums of Kibra, in Nyamira, youth lit bonfires to protest against the election of Kenyatta.
A Land Cruiser carrying five passengers was attacked by Al Shabaab militants at Arabia area. The driver was released and two passengers suffered gunshot wounds but they were in stable condition.

A group of young people tried to prevent Cabinet Secretary Matiangi from leaving the Gatina Primary School. The cabinet secretary had moved to address the crowd when people started chanting 'Matiang'i must go!'. Police used tear gas to disperse the agitated crowd that had started pelting stones at CS Matiang'i's motorcade, and then the school. Pupils who attempted to leave the school's premises got caught up in clashes, some being rendered unconscious while others gasped for air.

The altercation between the police and protesters at the Majengo bus stage began when a car belonging to a local businessman was allegedly found with marked presidential election ballot papers. One person was shot and at least 11 others were injured. Among those beaten up was a police in civilian uniform who ran to the scene.

Scores of angry men besieged the main entrance to the compound of the state broadcaster, Liberia Broadcasting System (LBS), blocking the main thoroughfare leading to the commercial district of Red-Light. The local area youth were demanding justice for their friend who was allegedly killed by an officer of the Liberia National Police (LNP).

A man was allegedly killed by an officer of the Liberia National Police (LNP). He was alleged to have been brutalized to death by the new head of the Zone 5 Police Depot located in the commercial district of Red Light.

An airforce raid on Darna led to the death of 15 civilians. It is unclear whether the Libyan National Army or the Egyptian Air Force conducted the raid. Both deny responsibility. Mada Masr reported that it had been told by an Egyptian government source that the airstrikes were carried out by the Egyptian air force. Also the DMSC accuses the EG military of carrying out the raids.
Military forces kill two members of Boko Haram as the fled on horseback at Gambo Yukku forest in Gubio LGA.
A vigilante group attack and kills three suspected motorcycle thieves.

Four soldiers reportedly died on Monday, while six others sustained injuries when troops of 152 Battalion, 21 Brigade of the Nigerian Army engaged Boko Haram at Banki in Bama LGA. It was reported the Boko Haram also suffered a "heavy loss". A second article from the same source claims 20 Boko Haram dead.
APC youth protest at their party's headquarters over alleged interparty corruption and called for the removal of a leader.
Limited reporting claims Al Shabaab have launched an attack on a SNA position IVO Bulo Burto. It is believed the government forces repelled the attack with no reported causalities.

actor1: AMISOM: African Union Mission in Somalia (2007-)
notes: Limited unconfirmed reporting claims that African Mission in Somalia (AMISOM) troops have engaged al Shabaab in the town of Buulo Mareer. Causalities not known.

actor1: AMISOM: African Union Mission in Somalia (2007-)
notes: Unverified media claims stated al Shabaab recaptured Ras Cadey, 12km from Baraawe, following the evacuation of the defensive position protecting the settlement by AMISOM forces.

An IED planted along the roadside by al Shabaab elements prematurely exploded at Daniga settlement (c. 11 km North of Balcad district). Security forces responded and recovered the bodies of the fighters. At least four al Shabaab operators were killed in the explosion. A second source claims the attack took place the following day.
30 October, An unidentified armed group assassinated a civilian in Hodan district. The motive of the attack is not known.
Al Shabaab executes a man on charges of spying.
Al Shabaab attacks and temporarily overtakes a checkpoint outside of Baidoa. Casualties not known.
Farmers in Cape Town protested over the murder of farmers throughout the country.
A handful of people gathered at the Memorial Circle in Kimberley in support of the national protest against farm murders.
At least 18 000 people and 5 000 vehicles have gathered at Kanonkop, a farm in Klapmuts near Stellenbosch in protest against farm murders.
Kwanobuhle residents burnt tyres after various parts of the area had not had electricity for several days.
Angry small, medium and micro enterprise owners and residents in Mdantsane shut down major construction sites in protest demanding BCM give local construction projects to its residents.
A multi-vehicle crash resulted in two people suffering serious injuries after a truck collided with a group of protesters on the N4 outside of Middleburg
An Eastern Cape university student has been beaten to death, allegedly by fellow students in Mthatha.
Pietermaritzburg and Midlands farmers joined the nation-wide protest against farm murders and attacks, causing backlogs in traffic on the N3 highway in Pietermaritzburg.
About 80 private doctors protested in Port Elizabeth demanding police action against armed robbers targeting their surgeries.
Farmers in Pretoria protested over the murder of farmers throughout the country.
A man fired at a police night patrol and a shootout was reported in Juba on 30 or 31 October. Circumstances unclear.

actor1: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: One SPLA-IO fighter died after a clash with one of his colleagues in Yambio. Reasons unclear.

actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: SPLA-IO claimed to have regained Ombasi on 2 November after around a week of clashes. The rebels claimed to have regained control of the area. They allegedly launched the attack after South Sudanese security officials denied civilians access to humanitarian assistance in Lasu payam.

actor1: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: Defection: Three armed opposition soldiers surrendered themselves and joined the government in Magwi County on the week of 30 October.

Leaders of the Habaniya and Salamat tribes signed a reconciliation and peaceful coexistence agreement in Buram. They agreed to hand over 1,420 weapons to the regular forces. They also called for pasture tracks and markets to be re-opened and for the establishment of a mechanism to deter the outlaws in the area and secure the voluntary return of displaced to their home villages.

RSF militiamen shaved a girl's head when they learned that she belonged to the Mahameed clan, headed by Musa Hilal. The girl was taking livestock for grazing near Damrat El Sheikh in Kutum locality. The incident raised significant tensions. Three days later, RSF opened fire on a vehicle carrying the girl and her father from Damrat El Sheikh, as they were on their way to Kutum to complain about the incident. Two people were wounded.
RSF defeated a SARC force in clashes in Shearia, East Darfur.

A residence for priests at St John of the Cross Parish in Malamba Mawili was attacked by a group of men aged 20-30. The raiders broke into the house through a window and stole several goods (laptops, mobiles, money, a tv set, ...). After breaking in, the raiders tied a security guard, taped his mouth and beat him. They also attacked some of the priests, beating and tying them. This was the third attack of its kind.

Dozens of professors admitted to CAPES, protested outside of the House of Representatives and tried to enter by force to meet deputies. Present security forces however, dissuaded them from trying to force their way.
Social Housing beneficiaries from Yellel, 20km east of Relizane, protested in front of the seat of the governorate to shed light on their bad housing conditions.

actor1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: A young man accused of arguing with a police officer was beaten by Imbonerakure in Kirundo.

assoc_actor_2: CACSC: Cameroon Anglophone Civil Society Consortium
notes: Two houses, belonging to the President of the now outlawed Cameroon Anglophone Civil Society Consortium, CACSC, Barrister Felix Agbor Nkongho, aka Agbor Balla, have been attacked by yet to be identified arsonists.

On October 28, a man was assaulted by 3 unidentified individuals in Ofa (about 7 km west of Kouango center). The circumstances of this aggression remain imprecise. The victim was admitted to the Kouango Health Center for treatment. Following this incident, members of an armed group equated with the victim's community of origin carried out reprisals in which one person was killed and four others seriously injured.

LRA forces looted the mining community of Yangou Waka, CAR. They reportedly fired their weapons upon arriving in the community and looted rice, sugar, soap, and cassava flour. They abducted 8 men and forced them to porter the looted goods.

actor1: Bokalakiti Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
actor2: Ngobi-Mayi Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: A long standing tension between the Kutu and Bokalakiti communal militias, due to forest products collection in the area, led to an armed confrontation between them. The leader of the Bokalakiti went to raid the Ngobi-Mayi with a revolver.
Militants target a police vehicle with an IED and then opened fire on the truck, killing two conscripts and wounding 10 on the outskirts of Al Arish.
Assailants open fire from Sinai on IDF troops conducting exercises on the border.

Three are dead and several others wounded in Nekemt after rumours of an illegally owned firearm by a civilian. Two of the dead are Amhara and one is Oromo. It is believed the protests are related to the wider unrest in the region. Other fatality recorded in event on 30/10.

Agazi special forces kill Oromos in Nekemt "over the weekend." The source states that the military has killed 30 over the past week, but with the exception of Ambo (10 dead) it does not provide details such as date and location. The number may have taken into account that attack at Bedele, though the perpetrating actor remains unknown.

The Northern Regional branch of the governing New Patriotic Party (NPP), has chided some youth group believed to be affiliated with the party for staging a violent protest against the national school feeding program. The group, that calls itself the Burma Camp Youth Wing, went on a rampage earlier this week,Â locking up the office of the school feeding programÂ at Oboabo, a suburb of Tamale in the Northern Region, over what they described as unfair allocation of schools to the regionâs caterers.
Kenyan police have used tear gas to disperse opposition supporters who threw stones after a government official visited a school in Kawangware.

Raid: on 29 October, armed men from Waithaka and Ndonyo area raided Kabiria. Young men were armed with pangas and threatened to conduct a door-to-door search to flush out Luos and Luhyas, who they said were living on their land. No actual violence reported.
One man was found dead in a sugar cane plantation one day after ethnic tensions between the Luo and Kalenjin communities got into an ethnic clash. The body had been hacked with a panga.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States
admin1: Tajura wa an Nawahi al Arba
notes: US special forces seized the second suspect in the Benghazi mission attack, Mustafa al-Imam, in Libya. Other info says that there was no actual operation and that the suspects were handen over to the US government by Libya Dawn militants who had already arrested them.
Islamic State militants set up a checkpoint in Wadi Hanaywa, 55 kilometers east of Sirte, during the first hours of Sunday morning.
Protesters gathered in Sirte to call on authorities to expedite the compensation for their homes destroyed and damaged.

A number of activists and civil society organizations protested in front of the Jafar municipal council in Houn to demand the dissolution of the council and refer its members to the judiciary, accusing them of corruption.
2 bandits were killed when they clashed with police in Ampefy.
FAMa repelled attack on checkpoint by 3 militants on motorbike at 4h in the morning in Ansongo at the exit of the town towards MÃ©naka

assoc_actor_1: MODEM: Nigerian Democratic Movement for an African Federation
notes: Twenty-three police were hurt and a police station was set on fire in demonstrations against financial reforms late Sunday in the Niger capital of Niamey. The Nigerien Democratic Movement, or Modem, were accused of being behind the protests and of being "tempted" by the "insurrectional model" in neighbouring Burkina Faso to gain power.
Boko Haram suicide bombers strike in the Muna Garage area. The Borno State Emergency Management Agency on Monday, confirmed that 17 people lost their lives and 18 others wounded.

actor1: AMISOM: African Union Mission in Somalia (2007-)
notes: Limited unconfirmed reporting claimed that African Mission in Somalia (AMISOM) troops have engaged al Shabaab in Baraawe. No known causalities.
Civilians protest against the Aynabo Peace Agreement. Demonstration instigated by pro-Puntland politicians. Event remained peaceful.
Al Shabaab attack SNAF checkpoint near Cabdow Dibile. No casualties reported, assailants repelled.
Suspected al Shabaab operative hurled a hand grenade against joint SNAF/SNPF checkpoint at Horseed/Hawo Takko junction. No casualties reported. Assailant escaped.

Al Shabaab attempt to kidnap four local NGO workers. ISWA responds. Armed clashes ensued. NGO vehicle destroyed by RPG round. Five ISWA soldiers injured when vehicle overturns on return to Baidoa. No casualties reported.
A village in Mdantsane went on the rampage and burnt a police bakkie as they tried to attack suspected criminals. Police dispersed the angry community with rubber rounds.

actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: Clashes between government and SPLA-IO forces 5km outside the UN camp in Bentiu town as the rebels were trying to bring wounded soldiers to the UN site for treatment.

actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: Clashes between government and rebel forces spread to Bahr Olo, Fergsika and Zangwa from 27-29 October after SPLA-IO ambushed a government forces' convoy on its way from Mundri to Maridi at Bamurye in Kajo Keji. Local residents claimed SPLA burnt houses in the area after they were defeated by the rebels, leaving six people killed.

actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: Defection: a group of six officers (including senior officers such as Lt. Col. Chan Garang and Major Aguer Atak Ariik) and 200 men, including members of the Mathiang Anyoor militia, defected from the ranks of the SPLA, denouncing the government's unwillingness to free former army chief Paul Malong from house arrest in Juba, delayed salaries and discrimination of other tribes. Some were said to have fled to an unnamed neihbouring country; others were said to have gathered north of Juba. A week later, Garang said the group had joined the ranks of the SPLA-IO led by Machar and claimed to be preparing military offensives against the government in Juba. The officers had allegedly attempted to free Malong from his residence but their attempts were foiled and led to the defection. The move raised fears of divisions within the army. Date unclear - report dated 29 October. The following week, president Kiir ordered the deployment of hundreds of forces around Malong's residence and the disarmament of his guards. The guards refused to hand their weapons, sparking further tensions in Juba.

actor1: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: Defection: a group of 370 youth from Apadang and Twic East areas of Jonglei state said they have joined the insurgency against the South Sudanese government led by SPLA-IO leader Machar. The group accused the government of causing suffering to the people of South Sudan and making the Dinka tribe targets of revenge.

Clashes between government and rebel forces spread to Bahr Olo, Fergsika and Zangwa from 27-29 October after SPLA-IO ambushed a government forces' convoy on its way from Mundri to Maridi at Bamurye in Kajo Keji. Local residents claimed SPLA burnt houses in the area after they were defeated by the rebels, leaving six people killed.

actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: SPLA-IO claimed to have regained Ombasi on 2 November after around a week of clashes. The rebels claimed to have regained control of the area. They allegedly launched the attack after South Sudanese security officials denied civilians access to humanitarian assistance in Lasu payam.

Government forces launched several offensives between 26-29 October in Kimu, Jalimo, Sokare and Bori villages of Kajo-Keji, a week after NAS claimed to have gained control of these areas from SPLA-IO. At least two civilians dead.
A gunman raided the shelter of a displaced woman in Kutum camp and shot and injured her when she resisted his attempt to rape her.
A group of herders in military uniform fired shots in the air and beat and injured two women who were trying to chase the herders' livestock from their farms near Gereida.
A group of Chadian soldiers abducted a student of the Holy Koran Institute in West Darfurâs Sirba locality. Reasons unclear. They also raided the premises.
Civil Society organized a protest march in Gabes to call for the swift completion of the construction of a new hospital.
Three Islamist 'extremists' assaulted a young man in Kairouan because of his un-Islamic behaviour. The young man had to be hospitalised.
Inhabitants from Monastir protested and prevented former President Moncef Marzouki from entering a local radio station.

assoc_actor_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: Imbonerakure held a march in Bubanza to celebrate the withdrawal of Burundi from the ICC.

assoc_actor_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: Imbonerakure and CNDD-FDD held a march in Bujumbura to celebrate the withdrawal of Burundi from the ICC.

assoc_actor_1: CNDD-FDD: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy
notes: CNDD-FDD party members carried out a demonstration in Busoni to celebrate the withdrawal of Burundi from the ICC.

assoc_actor_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: Imbonerakure held a march in Cankuzo to celebrate the withdrawal of Burundi from the ICC.

assoc_actor_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: Imbonerakure demonstrated in Gitega to celebrate the withdrawal from the ICC.

assoc_actor_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: Imbonerakure held a march in Gitobe to celebrate the withdrawal of Burundi from the ICC.

assoc_actor_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: Imbonerakure held a march in Kibago to celebrate the withdrawal of Burundi from the ICC. Students from local high schools were forced to participate.

assoc_actor_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: Imbonerakure and CNDD-FDD held a march in Kirundo to celebrate the withdrawal of Burundi from the ICC.

assoc_actor_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: Imbonerakure held a march in Muramvya to celebrate the withdrawal of Burundi from the ICC.

assoc_actor_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: Imbonerakure demonstrated in Muyinga to celebrate the withdrawal from the ICC.

assoc_actor_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: Imbonerakure and CNDD-FDD held a march in Mwaro to celebrate the withdrawal of Burundi from the ICC.

assoc_actor_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: Imbonerakure and CNDD-FDD held a march in Rumonge to celebrate the withdrawal of Burundi from the ICC. Taxi drivers say that they were forced to participate.

assoc_actor_1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: Imbonerakure demonstrated in Ruyigi to celebrate the withdrawal from the ICC.

DETONATION: 4 people were seriously injured following the explosion of a grenade in the Fatima district in the 3rd arrondissement. As a result, some households in nearby neighborhoods have left their homes to find shelter, elsewhere until Sunday, October 29
Two people were killed and another kidnapped by LRA elements in Pambayamba, a town 120 km from Sam-Ouandja on 28 October.

On October 28, a man was assaulted by 3 unidentified individuals in Ofa (about 7 km west of Kouango center). The circumstances of this aggression remain imprecise. The victim was admitted to the Kouango Health Center for treatment. Following this incident, members of an armed group equated with the victim's community of origin carried out reprisals in which one person was killed and four others seriously injured.
Different Mayi Mayi militia groups clashed in Loya on 28 October. One of the militias was headed by General Luc.

In East Hararge zone, Mayo Muluke woreda, security forces killed one Oromo young man. The forces fired bullets to disperse a crowd of people gathered to oppose security forces from taking Chat from Oromia region to areas controlled by the Liyu police force in Somali region.

Nine Fulani herdsmen and some Kwahu farmers (3 named persons) have been killed at Dwerebeafe, Aboyan and Mpeamu in the Kwahu East District. The killings occurred following aÂ clashÂ between Fulani herdsmen and some Kwahu farmers in the bush of those communities. A farmer and a 12 year-old boy are currently on admission at the Kwahu Government Hospital with gunshotÂ wounds.
25 Togolese have been arrested at Nima in Accra, for staging an unplanned protest calling for the exit of their embattled President, Faure Gnassingbe.
Kenyan police have used tear gas in an attempt to disperse crowds of opposition supporters in the Nairobi slum of Kawangware.
Villagers from the Luo and Kalenjin communities armed themselves against each other on 28 October in Kisumu County.
Police gunned down three men suspected of having killed the two police officers. They also recovered the stolen weapons and the AK-47s. The fighting lasted for 5 hours.
Rioters demonstrated in the town of Majengo. They were incited to attack a car which was said to have ballot papers, but after damaging it, it was not confirmed.
3 police officers mistaken for protesters were beaten on Saturday afternoon by other police forces in Majengo Town during ongoing demonstrations.

A protest rally was held by residents of Ajrah city to demand that the National Oil Corporation implement the promises regarding development that they made to the people of the city during their recent visit.

actor2: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
notes: IED targeting MINUSMA convoy detonated between 2 vehicles in the morning, axis Gao-AnÃ©fis. No casualties/damages

actor2: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
notes: In latest MINUSMA briefing, joint MINUSMA/Barkhane base in Tessalit subjected to indirect fire (mortar or rocket) .

Security forces imposed a lock-down and made some arrests after skirmishes with residents in al-Hoceima on the day of the anniversary of Mouhcine Fikri's death. Two brothers of the dead Fikri were reportedly arrested during the riots.

Hundreds of workers from the Moroccan refining company "Samir" marched yesterday to Casablanca to protest in front of the central headquarters of the Democratic Confederation of Labour, to demand the reopening of their company that has stopped production.
Protests took place in Rabat to commemorate the 1-year anniversary of Mohcine Fikris death which led to  unrest in the Rif region.

assoc_actor_1: BDS: Boycott Divestment and Sanctions Movement
notes: Boycott, Divestment & Sanctions (BDS) activists were arrested by police forces after protesting against the participation of an Israeli firm in the international date festival in Erfoud, Southeast Morocco.
Protests took place in Casablanca to commemorate the 1-year anniversary of Mohcine Fikris death which led to unrest in the Rif region.

Two suspected Boko Haram suicide bombers blew themselves up in what appears to be a failed mission at Magar village in Madagali Local Government Area of Adamawa state. Reports from witnesses in the area indicated that the two bombers who strapped improvised explosive devices on their bodies sneaked into the village in the early hours of 28/10 but the explosives detonated before they could reach their targets. A woman was however injured in the blast.
Military forces kill three members of Boko Haram at Dure. The force also engaged Boko Haram at Jango, Nduma, Gobara, Bala Ibrahim, Fulani Rogo, Takwala villages.
Military forces kill three members of Boko Haram at Dure. The force also engaged Boko Haram at Jango, Nduma, Gobara, Bala Ibrahim, Fulani Rogo, Takwala villages.
The Nigerian Army repelled an attempted attack on Goniri village in Yobe on 28/10. Casualties not known.

Hundreds of supporters of high-profile Senegalese mayor Khalifa Sall called for his release on Saturday as prosecutors asked parliament to lift his immunity from prosecution on graft charges. Dressed in items of red clothing, activists called for Dakar mayor Sall to be released after serving more than seven months in pre-trial detention on what they say are politically-motivated embezzlement charges. "Free Khalifa!" and "Khalifa until we die!" chanted around 300 people, many of them women and young people, after gathering a roundabout in the city's Medina district.
The leadership of the opposition Sierra Leone Peopleâs Party (SLPP) has condemned the stabbing to death of one of their supporters at Ogoo farm in Western of Freetown over the weekend.
28 October â Two groups of Somali soldiers clash at an unknown Mogadishu location. One person was allegedly killed. The reason for the exchange of gunfire is not known.
Suspected al Shabaab assassinated a federal district official at his home near Suuq Bacad market. One of the assailants was later killed by security forces.

Between two or three al Shabaab car bombers attackers target the Nasa-Hablod hotel, which is frequented by politicians and other members of Mogadishu's elite. 20 dead, 30 wounded. Later reports count 27 dead. Al-Furqaan report 50 dead. Al Shabaab claims 70 dead. The first VBIED detonated at approximately 17:00EAT.  The secondary VBIED was remotely detonated at approximately 17:40EAT. Following the blasts five gunmen stormed the hotel where they were they stayed until they were dislodged by SNG forces. Two dead, three captured.  Al Shabaabâs statement claiming responsibility was released at approximately 17:55EAT. Among the dead were nine Danab (Somali Special Forces).
Early AM, FOB Gaduud, Lower Jubba â al Shabaab fire several mortar rounds against the JSF base located near Gaduud. Causality figures not provided.
AM, IVO Cadale, Middle Shabelle â a Fedeal government convoy is targeted by an roadside IED. Outcome and perpetrators not known.
Suspected al Shabaab assassinated a federal district official at his home near Suuq Bacad market. One of the assailants was later killed by security forces.
Following a large attack on a Xamar Weyne, security forces engage the attackers, killing two and capturing three.

Approximately 300 local civilians stage a protest against the tenure of Somaliland elections in Baran. Unidentified gunmen opened fire, injuring nine. Puntland forces were subsequently deployed to the area.
Supporters of the Kulmiye and Waddani Somaliland political parties clashed in Ceerigaabo. Somaliland Police arrested six suspected perpetrators.

A communique published following a gathering of South Sudanese opposition groups over September/October announced the formation of a new rebel front against the government called the National Resistance Front/Army (NRF/A). It is unclear which opposition groups are involved in the new coalition. The group called for the removal of SPLM from power and vowed to fight to ensure South Sudan transforms into a Federal Republic with a rotational presidency (between Upper Nile, Equatoria and Bahr-el-Gazal), federal powers equally shared, and a diverse and professional national security sector.

The leader (identified as Amanya) of an armed group believed to have been carrying attacks on passengers travelling along the Torit-Juba road involving killings and lootings in the past few months was killed in a clash with security forces in Kor Lakbata in Torit.

actor2: Bor Clan Dinka Ethnic Militia (South Sudan)
notes: Twic county commissionner accused Murle youth from Boma of attacking Pading area of Twic county in Jonglei. In the clash with local Dinka youth, one of the attackers was killed.

actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: Clashes between government and rebel forces spread to Bahr Olo, Fergsika and Zangwa from 27-29 October after SPLA-IO ambushed a government forces' convoy on its way from Mundri to Maridi at Bamurye in Kajo Keji. Local residents claimed SPLA burnt houses in the area after they were defeated by the rebels, leaving six people killed.

Unknown gunmen shot dead the executive chief for Asole Boma of Lasu Payam in Agonya Kiri village, east of Lasu Payam, after leaving Mitika market. The reasons are unclear. Some officials accused armed opposition elements.

actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: SPLA-IO claimed to have regained Ombasi on 2 November after around a week of clashes. The rebels claimed to have regained control of the area. They allegedly launched the attack after South Sudanese security officials denied civilians access to humanitarian assistance in Lasu payam.

Government forces launched several offensives between 26-29 October in Kimu, Jalimo, Sokare and Bori villages of Kajo-Keji, a week after NAS claimed to have gained control of these areas from SPLA-IO. At least two civilians dead.

A group of around 20 herders opened fire on displaced farmers who were trying to remove the herders' livestock from their land near Mershing, leaving two shot dead. The herders exchanged fire with the military after a search team later found them at a nomad settlement in the area of Kerengo. Traders closed their shops at the mershing market in protest against herder violence.

A group of around 20 herders opened fire on displaced farmers who were trying to remove the herders' livestock from their land near Mershing, leaving two shot dead. The herders exchanged fire with the military after a search team later found them at a nomad settlement in the area of Kerengo. Traders closed their shops at the mershing market in protest against herder violence.
Security forces announced that they regained full control of Jebel Ouergha and the Kef mountains.

Inhabitants of Tataouine blocked roads with burning tires to show their insatisfaction with the results of competitive exams to be recruted for satellite companies of oil companies in the region. The exams were foreseen in the agreements to put an end to the month-long protests in Oued el Kamour several months ago.

After hooligans from 2 football clubs were rioting against each other in Helal, Tunis, throwing stones and using knifes, police intervened to stop the riots. The police however was heavily attacked by the hooligans which led to 4 policemen being injured and six policecars being damaged. Several hooligans were arrested.

300 residents from the Rubaare Town held a protest, accusing their legislator, Deputy Attorney General Mwesigwa Rukutana, of locking them out of the age limit consultative meeting. As 220 NRM members convened in Rubaare to discuss the amendment, they were blocked from entering the meeting and participating in the vote. With red bandanas tied around their heads, the demonstrators, who included youth and women, took to the streets.
The anti-riot police had to be called to put an end to the situation. They eventually fired teargas and rubber bullets to contain it.

Students started a riot, turning on each other, over the dispute of 2 male students who were competing for a girl who had recently moved to the school. The situation got out of control and turned out, with one house being vandalised.
Clashes between students of different schools when some refused to leave classrooms.
Property destruction: Attack in Tounte, gunshots fired near mosque, assailants burned the school.
A teacher was killed (hit with a pestle) by unknown in Gorom-Gorom.
2 men in Kibago were beaten by police officers.

actor1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: 2 Imbonerakure beat a man in Nyagisozi because he has not attended the CNDD-FDD party meetings.
A march against polio took place in Yaounde.

On 27 October, clashes between two armed groups were reported in Ngouala village (12 km from Mobaye, on the Mobaye-Zangba axis). The interim report, provided by local sources, reports 15 deaths, houses burned down and looting of property of locals.

On 27th October, peaceful protests occurred in Tadjourah, northern Djibouti, where a port is to be built. The protesters were demanding jobs. Several demonstrators were injured when the police used live ammo and teargas to disperse the protesters

Coptic inhabitants of Ezbet Zakariya in Minya, some 250km south of Cairo, were attacked by a Muslim mob because they were praying in a de facto church in the village. They threw stones at the Copts and broke the doors to their homes, wounding a Coptic woman. Police swiftly secured the scene and closed to church for fear of further unrest. Noone was arrested since the mob had dispersed quickly.

source: Xinhua News, Egypt Independent, BBC Monitoring, AFP English, Menastream
notes: Armed clashes between security forces and militants between al-Kharga and Assiut have led to the death of at least 12 militants. Bodies were transferred to Assiut University hospital.

Two members of the Agazi special forces were killed in an ambush carried out by unknown individuals in Ginchi 50 miles west of Addis Ababa. Two other members of the force were wounded in the grenade attack on a gas station, presumably in the same location.

Protests reported in Holeta, 24 miles west of the capital this morning with protesters blocking roads with rocks and burning tires. A truck was set ablaze and Agazi forces took control of the town later in the day.

Some irate youth of the New Patriotic Party (NPP)  calling themselves Party Royals, on Friday disrupted the election of a Presiding Member for the Adeiso District Assembly in the Eastern Region. The angry youth, known as the Party Royals, besieged a Pentecost Church where the election was taking place, and assaulted some Assembly Members, supposedly over their failure to vote for the partyâs preferred candidate, Eric Kwesi Mensah, for the position of presiding member.
Opposition suppoters went to the streets to ask for government's resignation
Angry protesters took to the streets, blocking roads to protest the decision to redo the elections on Saturday in certain counties. Rioters got into clashes with the police.
Angry protesters took to the streets, blocking roads to protest the decision to redo the elections on Saturday in certain counties.
Protesters took to the streets again to show their opposition to holding elections on Saturday. Outside Kisumu's morgue, 30 women stood weeping with signs saying "Stop killing our sons".

The police opened fire on protesters who were demonstrating against the decision to hold elections again on Saturday and killed two of them in Bungoma. The demonstrators blocked the road and lit fires.
2 Kenyan police officers are killed during an ambush in Nairobi. The attackers were armed with AK47s and they stole the officers weapons after killing them with shots from the back.

A man was shot dead while two others suffered gunshot wounds last Friday when they attempted to torch Mr Rege's home in Pala Village in Karachuonyo Constituency. Mr Rege confided to journalists that he suspected the MCAs were behind the plans to torch his home over allegations that there were ballot papers in his home marked in favour of President Uhuru Kenyatta.

Police raided houses of civilians in Kisumu, beating civilians and injuring dozens. Live bullets were used on some civilians, including a 14 year old boy. Of the 29 people injured, 26 had suffered gun shots.

source: Agence France Presse; Associated Press International; Daily Nation
notes: As a revenge to the previous event, the Kikuyu joined forces and attacked the Luo. The ethnic tensions and violence led to one severely injured person. Residents claims three were killed and dozens, including three school children, were injured.

source: Agence France Presse; Associated Press International; Daily Nation
notes: Rioters started throwing stones at the police in the morning, protesting against the elections to be held the next day. The police responded with teargas and water canons. The rioters were mostly from the Luo ethnic group and they took the opportunity to loot several stores, attack residents and to burn a store owned by an ethnic Kikuyu. One woman was raped.
Taxi drivers staged a protest and blocked roads in Analakey.
Dahalo bandits clashed with gendarme police forces in Antsotra_Maintirano, resulting in the deaths of 2 bandits.
A teacher was killed by Boko Haram men.
Military forces discover a cache of explosives and neutralize one member of Boko Haram in the northern Borno location of Ngalle.

Troops intercepted escaping Boko Haram fighters crossing Maiduguri-Monguno highway at Torowa village during which a fighter was shot dead, while others fled into the nearby bush. The troops recovered an AK-47 rifle with a magazine loaded with19 rounds of 7 62mm ammunition, three mobile phones, a SIM card and pieces of jewellery.
On 27/10 military forces carried out Boko Haram clearance operations at Gawa, Bone, Kajeri I, Kajeri II, Kube, Dubula, Boboshe I and Boboshe II villages in Borno State. No reported violence.

During a clearance operation military forces destroy a Boko Haram established market in Boboshe. It is believed the forces gained control of the area. No reported violence. The forces also cleared other areas in the region.
On 27/10 military forces carried out Boko Haram clearance operations at Gawa, Bone, Kajeri I, Kajeri II, Kube, Dubula, Boboshe I and Boboshe II villages in Borno State. No reported violence.
On 27/10 military forces carried out Boko Haram clearance operations at Gawa, Bone, Kajeri I, Kajeri II, Kube, Dubula, Boboshe I and Boboshe II villages in Borno State. No reported violence.
On 27/10 military forces carried out Boko Haram clearance operations at Gawa, Bone, Kajeri I, Kajeri II, Kube, Dubula, Boboshe I and Boboshe II villages in Borno State. No reported violence.
Students protest at the headquarters of Port Harcourt Electricity Distribution Company as well as the office of the governor after a school mate was electrocuted.
Confrontations between unidentified "farmers" and "herdsmen" (likely Fulani) in Yola South LGA causes two deaths on 25/10 and four deaths on 27/10.

assoc_actor_1: KYMCL: Kogi Youth Movement for Credible Leadership
notes: Some members of Kogi Youth Movement for Credible Leadership (KYMCL) on 27/10 staged a protest against the alleged donation of 1,260 bags of rice by some Senators to civil servants in Kogi. The protest was carried out along the Abuja-Lokoja highway causing gridlock as the youths trooped into the expressway for about an hour to express their displeasure over the donation.
27 October, evening, Marka, Lower Shabelle â clan militiamen assassinate two civilians. Clan identity, motive not provided.

actor1: AMISOM: African Union Mission in Somalia (2007-) (Kenya)
notes: KDF planes conduct an airstrike against al Shabaab positions in Dhasheq Wammo. Targeting grazing area whose access was restricted to local communities by al Shabaab. Causalities not known.
Al Shabaab hijacks two vehicles transporting medicine at Far Cusbo. Trucks taken to Dulmurux (40km north-east of Luuq).

An al Shabaab IED targets convoy transporting FGS Governor of Cadale near Goley. DC and two bodyguards injured. A civilian vehicle was also reportedly hit the same day in the same area by an al Shabaab IED. 3 injured.
Kulmiye supporters stone the house of Waddani Party figures. Somaliland Police arrest five suspected perpetrators.
Unidentified warplanes conduct airstrike against al Shabaab positions, possibly HVT. Outcome and resulting casualty figures unknown.

About five thousand people from various organisations, including parents and school children marched in support of safe schools and communities in the Western Cape. The protest was led by Equal Education (EE). They marched from Keizersgracht Street to Parliament and handed a memorandum to Allan Subban from the Department of Basic Education.
A design studio was set alight at Cape Peninsula University of Technologyâs (CPUT) Cape Town campus as sporadic protests continued at the institution.
The R21 and R24 highways near OR Tambo International Airport have been blocked by a taxi protest. Two Uber vehicles were set alight during protests on the R21 and R24 highways.
Classes were suspended at UCT as students again disrupted the academic programme in protest.

Jonglei state authorities accused Murle youths from Boma State of mobilising their forces in the areas of Gumruk, Manybol, and Lekuangole to carry out attacks on areas in Jonglei. The move they said aims at derailing the dialogue scheduled for next month between Murle and Dinka Bor communities. Report dated 27 October.

actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: Clashes between government and rebel forces spread to Bahr Olo, Fergsika and Zangwa from 27-29 October after SPLA-IO ambushed a government forces' convoy on its way from Mundri to Maridi at Bamurye in Kajo Keji. Local residents claimed SPLA burnt houses in the area after they were defeated by the rebels, leaving six people killed. FIve soldiers died and three were injured in the Bamurye ambush.

actor2: SPLA/M-In Opposition: Sudanese Peoples Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition
notes: SPLA-IO claimed to have regained Ombasi on 2 November after around a week of clashes. The rebels claimed to have regained control of the area. They allegedly launched the attack after South Sudanese security officials denied civilians access to humanitarian assistance in Lasu payam.

Government forces launched several offensives between 26-29 October in Kimu, Jalimo, Sokare and Bori villages of Kajo-Keji, a week after NAS claimed to have gained control of these areas from SPLA-IO. At least two civilians dead.
Unknown gunmen shot dead a police officer at Al-Siteb area of West Kordofan after the officer refused to hand them his keys and money.

RSF opened fire on a militant in Ghurra area, North Darfur, as he refused to cooperate during the RSF' disarmament campaign and drew a knife at them. The militant was wounded in the leg. Date unclear - report dated 27 October.

RSF militiamen shaved a girl's head when they learned that she belonged to the Mahameed clan, headed by Musa Hilal. The girl was taking livestock for grazing near Damrat El Sheikh in Kutum locality. The incident raised significant tensions. Three days later, RSF opened fire on a vehicle carrying the girl and her father from Damrat El Sheikh, as they were on their way to Kutum to complain about the incident. Two people were wounded.
Unknown militants abducted two people from a coal mine near Dubet Neira, 7km south of Dubo El Omda in North Darfur. The motives are unclear.

Militiamen attacked the area of Leiba in East Jebel Marra, leaving at least five people wounded and many others missing. The assaillants also stole around 1,000 heads of cattle and villagersâ belongings. Government troops stationed in the area reportedly fired into the air but did not come to the rescue.

assoc_actor_2: Al-Falata Ethnic Group (Sudan); Fur Ethnic Group (Sudan)
notes: A group of armed nomads attacked Fallata and Fur returnees in Funguli village, 54 km north-west of the team site at Menawashei, in East Jebel Marra locality, killing five and injuring several others.
A policeman from the mobile brigade of the judiary polices was attacked by three gunmen in Oued Dheb, Annaba. They exchanged shots before fleeing with their car. No injuries were reported.

On October 26th, 400 individuals tried to protest on the streets against the slow pace of their reintegration process. They marched through the streets of Luanda till they reached the General Command of the National Police. The police intervened and arrested a few individuals.

assoc_actor_1: F-SYNTER: Federation of National Unions of Workers in Education and Research
notes: Education workers went on a 48-hours strike to protest against bad work conditions. A march took place around the Education Ministry.
A trader was beheaded in Butaganzwa by unidentified attackers. As no money was stolen, it is believed to be a political murder.

actor1: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
notes: 4 youths in Rutegama were beaten by Imbonerakure because they have not registered for the CNDD-FDD.
DETONATION: explosion of 3 kamikazes that night in Mozogo. No other victims registered

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: The FARDC have been fighting since the afternoon of the 26th an insurgence from presumably the ADF in the city of Beni. The situation has caused some panic among the residents.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: A group of armed men attacked the Evangelical Hospital of Nyakunde. They beat a doctor, a nurse and some patients, taking also drugs and large sums of money. Around 9 to 10 people were assaulted.

Security forces killed three people in Ambo in an attempt to free trucks loaded with sugar that were held up by residents in protest. One of the trucks was set on fire by the protesters. The interrupted supply has caused sugar prices to recently rise. Oromiya Media Network reports the event occurred on 26/10, with 12 fatalities. At later report on 30/10 claims at least 10 dead.
In east Hararge zone, Jarso woreda Liyu police supported by Ethiopian federal army attacked a group of people, identity not known. Causalities not known.

Some rampaging youth believed to be sympathizers of the New Patriotic Party  (NPP) in Gwollu, the capital of the Sissala West District in the Upper West Region, today [Thursday], stormed the precincts of the Assembly and locked up the District Chief Executive, Mohammed Bakor in his office. They have accused the DCE of engaging in âdivide and ruleâ tactics, and failing to address their concerns. It took the intervention of the police to free the DCE.
In Mombassa, demonstrators lit tyres and timbers along the main highway.

Rioters firebomb a church in Mathare and barricade roads leading to poll stations with rocks. After anti-riot police was deployed, the situation was controlled. The director of the hospital of Drugnet told the AFP that there was 1 killed though.

Clashes break out in four western opposition strongholds, leading to shots and battles between police and demonstrators. Police and independent reports confirm 1 killed in Homa Bay and 1 seriously injured after a mob attacked a police facility.

In Kondele, one of Kisumu's slums, youth protest against the elections by barricating roads with huge stones, preventing police from approaching. Police later used water canons to disperse the protesters.
Clashes break out in four western opposition strongholds, leading to shots and battles between police and demonstrators.

Violent demonstrations break out in Kibera during the elections. Residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of their manifestation in support of Odinga. They also chained the gates of the Olympic Primary School to prevent voters from casting votes but the police managed to disperse them. Riot police fired teargas to disperse the crowds. Five people shot and injured.

Clashes break out in four western opposition strongholds, leading to shots and battles between police and demonstrators. Residents barricated roads, lit bonfires and paralised streets to prevent voters from casting their votes.
Angry villagers who saw that a teacher had marked ballot papers gathered to set fire to his house. The civilian had already sought refuge.

assoc_actor_1: IEBC: Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (Kenya)
notes: The IEBC announces that the voting for the presidential elections in Homa Bay, Kisumu, Migori, Siaya will be postponed to the 28th. The re-run was later cancelled with a new date to be announced.
A student is killed during protests in Kombewa

source: Xinhua; Nairobi News; Agence France Presse
notes: Riots break out in Kisumu, with demonstrators starting fires, erecting barricades and clashing with police. Three people are killed during the clashes
A Police officer on public order duty with other officers confronted a rioting mob blocking the Kisii - Oyugis road, was hit on the mouth with a stone hurled using a catapult
Two people shot dead in Baba Dogo, no mention of violence by the protesters.

A boy was shot dead in Makadara Shopping Center in Athi River when protesters engaged with police. Demonstrators blocked the Athi River-Makadara Road with stones and burnt tyres as police engaged them in running battles.
Police arrest 35 protesters who were barricading roads and disturbing the voting polls in Kakamega.
Young people pretending to be voters disturb the voting polls in Narok.

In North Karachuonyo, youths were repulsed after attempting to enter the home of former MP James Rege. Police say there were no injuries but reports indicate a man was shot and two others injured during the incident.
In Rangwe market, a police officer, who was escorting ballot boxes was injured after he was hit by a stone thrown by protesting youths.
Rioters/youth clash with police in Kakamega town. During the riots, a police officer mistakenly shot a National Youth Service officer in Kakamega.
A Returning Officer was attacked by demonstrators in Migori town on his way to the polling centre. He sustained slight injuries and lost a number of his personal items.
Residents kept off polling stations, choosing instead to protest an attack on Kisima Primary School polling station by a senior administration officer last Wednesday.
In Bungoma County, violent protests erupted in Kimilili, Chwele and Webuye leading to confrontations with police officers.
In Bungoma County, violent protests erupted in Kimilili, Chwele and Webuye leading to confrontations with police officers.
In Bungoma County, violent protests erupted in Kimilili, Chwele and Webuye leading to confrontations with police officers.
Youths use bees to keep voters away from Matsakha polling station and are eventually dispersed by police.

At Mugai Primary School, an assistant chief was chased away by angry locals who accused him of dishing handouts to coerce people to vote. Locals said the officer was giving people perceived to be Jubilee supporters Sh50 and directing them to the polling station to cast their ballots.
A crowd sets tyres on fire to protest the presidential election vote.

In Busia, a group of boda boda drivers stormed a polling station and burnt ballot boxes, forms 32A, 33, 34A, 41, supervisor validation forms, ballot papers, IEBC stamps, badges and reflector jackets, and stole two gas lanterns and cylinders.
One man was stabbed in the neck in Likoni, Mombasa. It is not yet certain whether he was attacked on the way to vote.

actor1: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
notes: 36 dead bodies were found in Al Abyar east of Benghazi. It is not clear who was responsible for the recent killings. The 36 were reportedly tortured before being shot in the head. Allegations exist that the victims were militants captured in Benghazi and subsequently held in military prisons of the LNA before being killed by them. The HRW later said that Haftar's forces were responsible for the killings.

actor1: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
actor2: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
notes: As fighting continues between LNA and BRSC militants in remaining pocket of Akhribish in Benghazi, BRSC says it killed a LNA fighter by sniping.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
actor2: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)

Local activists say Barkhane airstrike hit vehicle, killing three militants in Ti-n-Bidene, between Kidal and AbeÃ¯bara
Dozens of teachers staged a protest rally outside the provincial directorate of education in Meknes calling for an amendment of primary schools timetables in the commune of Wislan.

Disabled persons hold protests at ExxonMobil facilities at Ibeno and Eket. The protesters blocked entrances and forcibility entered the buildings on 25/10 and 26/10. The protesters demanded social welfare from the company.
Military forces kill three Boko Haram and wound others at Lumda in the early morning hours of 26/10. The forces also recovered weapons.
A group of five unidentified gunmen abduct a monarch from his home in Ikot Nya.

Al Shabaab fighters conducted a probing attack against a South West State force position located at the southern outskirts of Diisnoor district (c. 115 km South West of Baidoa). There was an exchange of gunfire after which al Shabaab retreated from the scene. There were no reports of casualties.
Early AM, Sarmaan, Bakool â fighters loyal to Sheikh Mukhtar Robow attack al Shabaab positions on 26/10. Causality numbers not known. A similar clash in the area occurred the previous day.
Reports claim that further clan based violence have erupted in settlements to north of Galkacyo at Godad and Galcadale. Six deaths reported between the two locations.
Reports claim that further clan based violence have erupted in settlements to north of Galkacyo at Godad and Galcadale. Six deaths reported between the two locations.
Al Shabaab forces attack a Jubaland military base at Buulo Gaduud. Four soldiers and an officer dead. Other injured. Later reports indicate 6 Jubaland fighters KIA and 10 al Shabaab fighters KIA.
Al Shabaab stones a woman to death on claims of adultery. A second source indicates the event occurred on 27/10.
At least seven people have been injured after Badhan police opened fire on demonstrators protesting against the Hargeisa administration.

actor1: AMISOM: African Union Mission in Somalia (2007-) (Uganda)
notes: Defusal: UPDF foot patrol discovers an al Shabaab IED. Device safely detonated.

actor2: Military Forces of Somalia (2017-) National Intelligence and Security Agency
notes: VBIED factory explodes. 1 KIA 2 WIA. NISA arrest two.
Members of a community allegedly stoned a 50-year-old man to death in Rabokala near Brits.
A  group of Right2Know campaign members picketed outside the city hall demanding that the full council reject proposed amendments to the Rules of Order.
A group of pupils allegedly stole cash and laptops from the staff room and set the school property alight in ongoing violence.

The group joined the ranks of the SPLA in Wunyiik area, Northern Bahr al Ghazal.
